Thus, depending on the content of the conditional branch to be described, the weighted sum paradigm is easier to describe than the rule-based paradigm
The examples listed here have not yet utilized weights.
By adjusting the weights, you can reflect the level of importance in your judgment, such as "whether x1 is true is important, whether x3 is true is not so important".
Supervised learning" is a system in which the weights are not adjusted by humans, but by using "supervised data," which is "the results we want to obtain under these conditions.
[Epoch in which the rule-based paradigm lost out to the weighted paradigm].
In 2012, the rule-based paradigm loses to the weighted paradigm.

In the ILSVRC-2012 (ImageNet Large Scale Visual Recognition Challenge), a contest for image recognition accuracy, AlexNet, created by deep learning in the weighted sum paradigm, won by a wide margin over a rule-based implementation devised and designed by humans. AlexNet won the competition.

The contest challenged participants to correctly classify 50 images in each category for testing, using 1,300 images in 1,000 categories each. While the previous year's winner had failed to classify 26.2% of the images, AlexNet improved by more than 10 points all at once to win at 15.3%.
It has been demonstrated that a mechanism to adjust weights performs better than a human working hard to design features and describe them as rules.

Research in this direction has since accelerated, and in 2015, ResNet-152 reached a failure rate of 3.57% with a consensus of six models with different parameters. Since the failure rate for humans is 5.1%, the performance of ResNet-152 exceeded that of humans in this contest.
statistical language model
This paradigm shift spread to other areas.
For example, machine translation
Humans had a unit called "word" and an attribute called "part of speech" in a "sentence" and tried to combine them with the rules of "grammar" to understand sentences
This process of chopping sentences into words and identifying parts of speech is called "morphological analysis," which many readers may have heard of.

In 2018, a study was published showing that statistically separating sentences into words in morphological analysis improves machine translation performance rather than separating sentences into words. One of the authors is Taku Kudo, a well-known developer of the morphological analyzer MeCab. Unlike conventional Japanese morphological analyzers, the proposed "SentencePiece" does not have a Japanese-specific dictionary or grammatical rules.

In the past, humans created the concept of "word," and then created a system based on the idea that "words must be divided into word units. In fact, however, the "word-by-word segmentation" was a restriction created based on an assumption, and the performance of machine translation was improved by removing this restriction.
Large-scale language model (LLM)
As of 2025, computers now have the ability to understand language at the college level

This is due in large part to the language-independent tokenizer mentioned earlier. The language-independent tokenizer enables the centralized handling of data on the Internet that is written in a variety of languages, and sometimes in a mixture of languages.

ChatGPT was released in November 2022, and the GPT-3.5 used inside it is said to have the language understanding capability of a college student. As of July 2025, a model with performance equivalent to GPT-3.5 can be run on a laptop computer without an expensive GPU.
This greatly lowers the language barrier.
Let's divide them into "language barriers between people and computers" and "language barriers between people and people."
Language barriers between people and computers
Until now, computers lacked the ability to understand human language, so humans learned a "programming language" and used it to give instructions to computers. That is "programming.

Programming languages have strictly defined grammars, so the meaning is determined on a rule basis. This is the reason why they could be used even by computers with limited language comprehension ability.

As computers become more capable of understanding language, it becomes more cost-effective to give instructions to computers in natural language. Andrej Karpathy (one of the founding members of OpenAI), who coined the term "[vibe coding]," says he doesn't even touch the keyboard because voice input is sufficient.
Many may not yet consider it a decent programming method because of its high failure rate, but within a few years it will perform well enough for most use cases.
[https://gyazo.com/78a6a9aa82f0d0f623829f63637a7c73]
[Part of it disappears, part of it remains, and a new one is born.] X shifts to X'. a: what disappears b: what remains c: what is newly born
What is now considered the work of software engineers will surely disappear in part. Some will remain, and new areas will be created.
Language barriers between people
The author believes that there will be fluctuations in society as a whole that are incomparable to the fluctuations in the field of software engineering.
This is because the number of cases in which "something that acts as if it were a person" is not a person increases to a non-negligible percentage.

Services that allow AI to directly control the browser are emerging, such as Cognition AI's Devin and ChatGPT's Operator mode, which is still only available in the U.S. As of 2025, AI can obtain its own email address, get past the [CAPTCHA] to repel robots, and create accounts for various services, It can create accounts for various services. Any service open to the Internet can be used by non-human users.

Many of you have probably seen accounts on X (Twitter) that hang on to posts that have attracted attention. You can tell when you see one that is poorly done, but there will be some that successfully pretend to be human. Soon the time will come when it will be impossible to tell whether the person on the other end of the phone is a human or a machine.

AI allows one person to pretend to be 10,000 people. Human thought patterns that lead people to believe what many people are saying can be easily controlled by the entities operating such systems. This risk is often discussed in terms of [cognitive warfare] and [public opinion polls].

It's not all bad. For example, advances in machine translation have made it easier to cooperate with people who speak different languages. Difficult texts can be explained and furigana added for elementary school students. What used to be done through language becomes generally less expensive.
Advances in LLM will bring about major cost structure changes in "communication", a major component of "society".
Something similar has happened many times in history in the form of letterpress (≈books), radio, and the invention of the Internet
Society is greatly affected each time and cannot return to its previous form.

The advent of books made it possible to understand the Bible in one's native language. This broke the clerical monopoly of knowledge held by the Latin language and led to the Reformation and the development of science.

The advent of radio made it possible for a sender to communicate information to a country's population in a highly real-time manner. 1933 saw the spread of inexpensive radio under Hitler's regime, and the simultaneous listening of many citizens to broadcasts from the Ministry of Propaganda influenced the formation of consciousness in society as a whole.
It is impossible to explain in a few words what the advent of the Internet has changed.
How will the advent of LLM change society in the future?
LLMs don't just change communication.

So far, we have seen a number of cases where the "computation" that humans have worked hard to define, construct, and design rules for has been defeated by the "computation" learned by the neural net.
Could the same be said of the rules called "laws" that humans have created to describe social systems?
[The law is society's operating system.]
A "society" described by law may lose in performance to a "society" weighted by neural nets.

In what form would this "performance difference" manifest itself? Will it be a difference in economic growth rates? Or will it be, as in the case of ENIAC, "the difference between computational power and military power"? A few days before writing this article, I saw a news report that 30,000 attack drones equipped with image processing AI and capable of automatically tracking targets were exported to the ongoing war between Russia and Ukraine. The day before that, a drone had invaded a nuclear power plant in Japan, causing a commotion. I believe that the social changes that are currently taking place are not far-fetched.
Ideology in the 21st Century
Today, in 2025, there are three ideologies of "what kind of society is better" as technology transforms society
(This is discussed in the book "Plurality" written by Audrey Tang and Glen Weyl in 2024.)
Simply put, efficiency, freedom, and cooperation.
Focus on efficiency
Let's leave everything to AI, humans are inefficient."
Some people believe that the ideal situation is one in which AI does all the work and humans can live without having to do anything.
Maybe in the distant future there will be a future where humans don't have to do anything.
But in the near future, the division of labor will be such that "AI will do what is more efficient to do, and humans will do the rest.
The problem here is that if the AI is better at decision making, the AI will make the decisions and the human will have to work as an unwilling tool!

For example, in the shipping process in a huge warehouse like Amazon's, the AI knows what is on what shelves and decides which route to take, and the human takes it off the shelves and puts it in the box as instructed.
Efficiency and freedom are often trade-offs
When AI can direct optimal behavior, human free will is a detrimental efficiency loss
There will be financial penalties for inefficiency, etc., to train people not to try to make free decisions.

Many of our readers may have received their school education in Japan, where peer pressure is strong. In order for a small number of teachers to manage a large number of students, many of them may have been taught to act collectively by watching their surroundings and reading the atmosphere, rather than moving freely and arbitrarily. In an efficiency-oriented society, this atmosphere will prevail.
Emphasis on freedom
Strongly opposed to the efficiency-oriented approach is the freedom-oriented approach.
The idea is that it is more important for each individual to be free to do what he or she wants to do than to be efficient as a whole.
We believe that laws and regulations should be relaxed and privacy should be strengthened to prevent the government from observing individual behavior.
destruction of public property
The trouble is, there are many types of things in society that break down when everyone gives them free rein!
It's a case of personal freedom having a negative impact on others.
Classic analogy [Tragedy of Common Land].
The metaphor that if everyone fed the cows freely in a shared pasture, the pasture would die.
Should the free release of gases that degrade the global environment be promoted?

On a more individual level, is it a freedom that should be promoted to "mix and discard properly because it is a hassle" in an area where the rule is to separate garbage and throw it away? Is it acceptable for people who do not know how to dispose of mobile batteries to mix them with regular trash? Restoration is estimated to cost billions of yen. Since the cost of public facilities is ultimately covered by your taxes, a few tens of yen of your taxes will be used for the restoration.
[How to deal with the tragedy of shared lands in OSS]
In 2022, the developer of the open source library "colors.js" refused to "work for free" because of economic hardship and intentionally tampered with the library
OSS "free to use" leads to financial ruin for maintainers as "no one pays for its upkeep"
How can we better fund this type of public good?
Freedom widens the gap.
Freedom widens the gap between those who can take advantage of that freedom and those who cannot

For example, Japan's Foreign Exchange Law was amended in 1998 to allow, in principle, free investment in foreign stocks and other securities. This is in contrast to China, where foreign currency purchases and remittances are limited to US$50,000 per year.

Thanks to this freedom, Japanese people have the freedom to buy tens of millions of yen worth of U.S. stocks. However, this "everyone has the freedom to do it" does not mean "everyone can do it. Many people may not have the political and financial means to buy tens of millions of yen in U.S. stocks.

Those who have bought U.S. stocks in the past decade have, on average, earned 10~20% annual gains, increasing their assets by about 3~6 times in 10 years. On the other hand, nominal wages for the average Japanese worker have only grown by about 4% over the past decade, and have rather decreased when prices are taken into account. And for those who can move their assets to growing foreign countries, there is no real personal harm if Japan does not grow and workers' wages do not increase.
Only those who were able to learn about the beneficial alternatives from the large number of choices and could afford to take those alternatives could reap the benefits of freedom.

Meanwhile, in China, where foreign currency restrictions were strict, bitcoin became an attractive investment as a way to circumvent regulations. The use of bitcoin as a means of anonymously transferring funds out of the country began to spread rapidly around 2013, and the authorities decided to close exchanges in 2017 and ban bitcoin altogether in 2021.

So advances in cryptography provide enhanced privacy, which is a means of increasing freedom for those who want to act without being monitored by the government. And the extent to which governments allow freedom varies from country to country. Japan is tolerant of individuals investing in foreign stocks, but it is not entirely free. For example, "cases where people want to act without being monitored by the government" include funding for terrorism and money laundering of criminal proceeds. The Japanese government is considering thoroughly "ascertaining the identity of the sender and receiver" in order to prevent these activities, but there are various technical challenges in the situation due to the combination of cryptocurrencies' high degree of anonymity.
This tradeoff between efficiency and freedom is also related to the classic [Big Government and Small Government] debate.
Centralized mechanisms tend to increase the efficiency of public goods supply, but uniform regulation tends to undermine freedom.
Leaving it to the market will increase autonomy and freedom of choice, but it will also reduce efficiency due to free-riding and external diseconomies, and will lead to widening inequality.
Balance is important, not one extreme or the other; which balance is appropriate?
Emphasis on cooperation
The "trade-off between efficiency and freedom," the "big government/small government dichotomy," and "how to balance the two" are false assumptions
[Big government/small government" is a false dichotomy.]
The claim that there is a third pole
Elinor Ostrom, 2009 Nobel Prize in Economics
from  [ostrom]

>Ostrom studied [public goods (i.e. goods or services such as parks or highways)] and [shared resources] ([CPR], [Common-pool resource]). He challenged the earlier assertion that either the government or the market would deal with the management of public goods and CPRs, and showed that the efficiency of managing resources is most effective when neither the market nor the government, but the community, plays a complementary role.
(The use of the word "efficiency" here is confusing.)
The third axis of 21st century ideology is "Let's use technology to help people cooperate".
Audrey Tang: [Connections between indivisuals as first-class objects]
Model society as an [intersecting group] rather than as a single system or as a collection of disparate individuals
[https://gyazo.com/6372900530b7163c3ae1bcacc73be72f]
from [intersecting group]
Overall Optimization -> Thinking to optimize the whole as a single instance
Maximizing individual freedom -> thinking to optimize the individual as a single instance
Individuals belong to a number of small groups.
Family, community, company, region, ...
We will make sure that better teamwork occurs within this small group.
This small group is generated and extinguished.
[https://gyazo.com/996f462ac6623efec6a8a467e9dd76ee]
For example, people belonging to different groups come together temporarily to work together on a project.
At this time, groups that straddle "group boundaries" are being created.
We consider it a good thing that this "bridging group" is being created more and more.
From the union of different things, something new is born.
Why is it good if a "bridging group" is created? Because better results are achieved when people belonging to different groups bring their wisdom together.
And [one cannot estimate the value of a new thing before its appearance].
So we're going to create a lot of opportunities, some of which will lead to big results that can't be predicted in advance.
Streamlining communication lowers "bring it on" costs.
Lower language barriers are also relevant here.

Not only Japanese-English translation, but also within the Japanese language, there are "seemingly identical Japanese speakers who cannot communicate with each other," and we will smooth out these language barriers that are difficult to see and have not been invested in resolving until now.
As of 2025, how are society's calculations being updated?
The "Plurality" by Audrey et al. is a more detailed catalog.
Development of LLM
[broad listening]
[https://gyazo.com/8aed1a6ee239c672d1e504cdb48d0e9e]
The development of technology to duplicate and distribute information has made it easier for one person to communicate ideas to a large number of people.
However, when a large number of people transmit information, the volume of information received by one person becomes enormous, and the person drowns in the flood of information.
In a society and company where people actively communicate, technology that supports listening to the opinions of many will be important.
[Talk to the City] created by [AI Objectives Institute] and [public information AI] developed by the [Digital Democracy 2030] project based on it.
pro-social media

Let us imagine, for example, an electronic bulletin board on the Internet. Roughly speaking, for every 100 people on the Internet, there will be at least one person who makes a personal attack or has a harsh tone. Once such a person appears, about 3 out of 100 people will begin to emotionally rebut him or her, or say, "That kind of language is not good," or attack the individual who made the assertion in a harsh manner. Once this cycle begins to turn, the place for productive discussion is destroyed.
Can we design social media in such a way that more productive discussions can take place? This is the idea of pro-social media

For example, [Polis] is designed so that people vote for and against opinions, and attention is drawn to those commonly agreed upon by different opinion groups. Opinions that are radical and divisive are immediately hidden from view.
[Your Priorities] allows you to post an opinion for or against a topic, but not a reply to a specific opinion.
The common denominator for both is the importance of a system that does not allow them to reply to each other.
In the words of Audrey Tang, "[I]f the left is making good arguments, all the right has to do is make equally good arguments, not fight."
Support for deliberative discussions
Broad Listening is using LLM to "augment the ability to hear many voices."
pro-social media was designed to help people discuss things better using pre-LLM technology
The development of LLM allows for a system that directly supports people to better discuss
(I will write about [IIDOBATA system] later.)
The World Computer called Ethereum
In 2015, Ethereum begins operating. It is the birth of "a general-purpose computer that can compute common content while being globally distributed.
A common "state" is written and shared around the world on the blockchain, and the EVM (Ethereum Virtual Machine) executes side-effect-free byte code to match the state transitions of all nodes.
This created a "world computer" that is globally distributed and logically performs a single calculation, in which anyone can participate and which will not stop as long as someone else participates.
Ref: [Three axes of centralization].
Automation of Execution

In the past, human societies used a system in which "contracts" were made on paper, and when those contracts were broken, civil lawsuits were filed and eventually enforced by state power. The cost of these contracts and civil suits is very high.

On the other hand, the implementation of "what process is to be performed under what conditions" as EVM code has made it possible to automatically enforce contracts in a way that does not depend on the power or legal knowledge of a particular state. This is the smart contract.

Prior to this, software services were still able to provide functionality to the entire world. The advent of smart contracts became a source of trust in contracts that did not depend on "trust in the operator or the state in which it resides.
prediction market
This trust through smart contracts has helped stimulate the forecasting market
It is now possible to create a market anonymously, bet money anonymously, and take it from the losers and give it to the buyers through automated execution.
In Japan, prediction markets using real money have not received as much attention as in other countries because of the risk of being considered gambling.
On the other hand, in the world's largest prediction market [Polymarket] (2020~), for example, more than USD 3.6 billion has been spent on who will win the US presidential election in 2024.
[https://gyazo.com/7e4782c51c8cda9ffe98457e2bffb4be]
[Polymarket | Presidential Election Winner 2024 https://polymarket.com/event/presidential-election-winner-2024?tid=1754025017161]

Anyone can say irresponsible things in social networking posts. You can make a strong claim that you are confident, even if you are not. But in the prediction market, how much you are betting on your opinion is a signal of confidence.
This makes the forecasting market a "collective knowledge system with confidence information" different from social networking.
Decision-making algorithms
One algorithm is to vote and make a majority decision.
One algorithm is to let the prediction market decide
At present, the commodity futures market is still considered to be a mechanism for predicting the supply and demand of commodities and determining future prices.
Expanding this to more diverse is the forecasting market.
[Futarchy] is a system of governance in which people vote on what they want to achieve and leave it to the prediction market to decide how to achieve it.

The author does not believe that this method is optimal, but he finds it interesting that one of the options for adjusting the parameters of society is to consider a system determined by an algorithm rather than by human beings making laws in a legislative body.
In Japan, we are left out of these experiments due to laws that do not allow for prediction markets.
summary
I thought about "society" as "human computation" and how it could be improved from the perspective of computer science.
memo
[Thinking of society as a human computation, v1, second half].

lines.text: Examples of Fraudulent Crime Hazard Prevention
[Taiwan Fraud Prevention Act].
[o3.icon]

In the ongoing development of the Fraud Prevention and Control Act in Taiwan, the Ministry of Digital Development (MODA) and vTaiwan jointly conducted an online debate - the largest "[ mini-public]" directly reflected the consensus opinions of the public in the draft articles (Articles 30-32). The CommonWealth Magazine article detailing the process in English is the most comprehensive and primary source of information.
[Using AI to Strengthen Democracy: Audrey Tang on Taiwan's Global Role｜Culture｜2024-10-21｜web only https://english.cw.com.tw/article/article.action?id=3795&utm_source=chatgpt.com]
More than 200,000 people expressed their opinions on pol.is and discussed them in mixed online/offline workshops.
The generated consensus text is adopted in Articles 30-32 of the draft "Prevention of Fraud and Crime Harm.
Positioned as "the largest online mini-public in history" in the deliberative democracy that Taiwan has promoted since 2002.
[o3.icon]

Taiwan's Fraud Crime Hazard Prevention Act ("Fraud Prevention Act"), promulgated on July 31, 2024, imposes heavy KYC obligations and prompt removal responsibilities on large advertising platforms that are the source of online fraudulent advertising, By imposing heavy KYC obligations and prompt removal liability on large advertising platforms that are the source of online fraudulent advertisements, the Act has nearly eliminated fake ads impersonating celebrities that were rampant on Facebook and YouTube. This law was passed by the Legislative Yuan the following year as one of the "Four Laws on Batting Fraud" after the Executive Yuan adopted a proposal compiled in an online debate facilitated by AI, which divided 450 citizens recruited from 200 k random SMSs into 45 chambers at the end of 2023.
[Audrey Tang on “Misinformation” - by Yascha Mounk https://www.persuasion.community/p/audrey-tang-on-misinformation]
From participatory processes to legislation
In 2023, 200 k SMS convened on the issue of false advertising → 450 statistically representative applicants selected → 10 x 45 rooms for AI-facilitated discussions.

The discussions resulted in agreements such as "advertisers' obligation to sign digital signatures" and "platforms' compensation for damages." Based on these agreements, the Executive Yuan approved the "Anti-Fraud Package" by the Cabinet on May 9, 2024.
The Legislative Yuan passed the bill on July 12 of the same year and promulgated it on July 31.
Applicable to-- "online advertising platforms of a certain size".
Designated by MODA based on monthly active users, etc. Six companies (Google/YouTube, Meta (Facebook/Instagram), LINE, and TikTok) were named to the initial list.
Overseas businesses are also required to establish a legal representative in Taiwan.
4. core obligations
KYC/identification
Verification of advertisers' and financiers' status and area of residence, and simultaneous disclosure in advertisements
Deletion within 24 hours
Government reporting or outright fraudulent ads removed or suspended within 24 hours Child law "notice deadline standard"
Transparency Report: Annual "Fraud Prevention and Control Transparency Report" published
Legal representative: Notify representative residing in Taiwan, clarify responsibility for service in case of violation Article 27 ②.
Penalties: NTD 500,000-10 million per violation, up to NTD 100 million for major violations + access blocked
brief summary

This law is groundbreaking in that it was designed "without the government censoring the content, and imposes identification and liability for compensation on the platform," and quickly institutionalized the consensus of citizen discussion. The future success or failure of this law will depend on the strictness of its operation and measures taken to prevent its spread to other services.

QA with Leon Erichsen
[Leon Erichsen]
1. What do you see as the most urgent or overlooked issues in Japanese society today?
What do you think is the most urgent or overlooked problem in Japanese society today?

Many people think that the development of AI is not "a change in the environment that affects everyone" but only "a change in the tools used by some people." Some people criticize the manifesto of Anno et al. by saying that it is "about means and not ideology." Plurality's "Three Ideologies for the 21st Century" is a discussion about how to deal with technology, but I don't think the framework of that discussion is understood yet. This is an overlooked issue.

The most urgent issue is that the pension system is failing due to the declining birthrate and aging population. The younger working generation will suffer from the burden of social security contributions to support the elderly and accumulate hate toward the elderly generation. In a democracy, "the elderly, who outnumber the young," have more power, and politicians also focus their activities on the elderly. As this intergenerational conflict grows, the forces that seek to wrest power back from the elderly through violence, rather than through democracy, become stronger.
2. How would you describe your role in the Mirai movement -- what you do, and how you feel within it?
2. how would you describe your role in the MIRAI movement - what you do and how you feel in it?

When Anno was running for Governor of Tokyo, she was working on a project to visualize public opinion using Talk to the City. Anno has been involved in the design phase of kouchou-ai, an OSS tool for broad listening released by Anno in March, and is one of the code owners. (The main developer is Sumino Nasuka, who is running as one of the candidates in this election.)

As for this campaign, I don't think we have done any obvious and conspicuous activities because we are looking at various information as an engineering ranger and doing activities where necessary. This time, for the Team Mirai volunteers, we have made the AI agent Devin available for unlimited use by those who wish to use it. We implemented a backend for visualization of the amount of donations received by the team. We implemented a visualization of volunteers' geographic locations based on their zip codes; we created a mechanism for AI to process over 2,000 proposed amendments to policy proposals published on GitHub. To summarize, one might say that we are facilitating information distribution.
3. If Mirai were to succeed, what kind of Japan do you imagine? What would feel different in daily life?
If MIRAI were to succeed, what kind of Japan do you imagine? What would be different in your daily life?

Depends on the definition of success. We believe there is a fairly high probability that the party will be successful. In that case, we will have a pro-technology party with a leader who has a solid experiential understanding of using AI to improve productivity. I see this as akin to blowing a hole in the dike. If a hole is drilled, water flows through it and the hole gets bigger and bigger.

I have not discussed and agreed with Anno on this topic, but I believe it is also related to Answer 1. I think it would be good if the energy of intergenerational conflict were used to make the system better through technology rather than through the use of force through physical violence. I believe that by creating an initial pathway to this end, we will succeed in the long run in alleviating the problems of an aging society without becoming violent.
[The challenge is to reduce the probability of a violent revolution against the elderly.]
[Righteous bandits could become popular among young people.]
[The "Fraud is Social Justice" Narrative]

I was curious whether you’ve seen moments where this generational conflict has already tipped into more emotionally or physically violent territory. You described the risk so clearly -- and I can see how that underlying tension could easily intensify.

I was curious if you have seen a moment when this generational conflict has already plunged into emotionally or physically violent territory. You have described the risks very clearly, but I can see how the underlying tension could easily intensify.
Police are troubled by the increase in fraud cases targeting the elderly.
2024: 21,043 cases, 71.88 billion yen, +10.5% (number of cases)/+58.8% (value) from the previous year
https://www.npa.go.jp/bureau/criminal/souni/tokusyusagi/hurikomesagi_toukei2024.pdf

The perpetrators of this scam are known to conduct their training with narratives such as "The elderly are hoarding money because it is their death money, and it is justice to take it and distribute it to the poor," or "Our generation is the victims who are forced to pay high Social Security contributions and will not be able to receive the benefits themselves because they will be bankrupt by the time they reach the elderly. It is known that the training is based on the narrative that "our generation is the victim.
Violent behavior includes
Famous for a widespread robbery that took place in 2022.
https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/ルフィ広域強盗事件
This past June, another 140 thefts targeting the homes of elderly people while they were sleeping occurred, and three suspects, including a 25-year-old suspect, were arrested.

We know that Telegram was used in the former case, and I think the main problem is that it increases the security of the ringleaders and the know-how gained in the execution is distributed while maintaining anonymity.
Kouchou-AI is based on Talk to the City, with additional functionality added based on the need felt from practice in Japan by Yasuno and others.

polypolitanism
[o3.icon]What is polypolitanism?

Polypolitanism is a theory that institutionalizes the reality that "everyone belongs in multiple layers" and proposes a new citizenship architecture appropriate to an era in which mobility and diversity are the norm. Although it is proposed as an entry point for immigration policy, it is essentially a comprehensive vision that redesigns all social institutions in a "superimposable" manner.

The proponent is the American political philosopher [Daniel Allen] (Harvard), a concept detailed in his book [Justice by Means of Democracy] (2023) and article "[Polypolitanism: An Approach to Immigration Policy to Support a Just Political Economy]" (2022).
Etymology poly- (polycentric) + polity ([political community]) + -ism
To design a system that transcends the "nation-state/non-nation-state" dichotomy and allows individuals to participate equally in politics while belonging to multiple overlapping polities.
Three Core Ideas
[Stratified Membership]
People belong to multiple polities simultaneously, such as families, municipalities, professional associations, and the state. These "bundles" form identities and rights and obligations.
Example: gradual granting of rights, such as the right to vote in city council elections after 3 years of residence, the right to vote in some national offices after 10 years of residence, etc.
[Gradient Citizenship]
Loosen the citizen/non-citizen switch, and accumulate points and rights based on years of residence, social contributions, and tax payment performance.

Example: [Soul Bound Token]([SBT]) to prove community contribution and earn rights - Web3 paper also cited ([alzhacker.com https://alzhacker.com/decentralized-society-finding -web3s-soul/?utm_source=chatgpt.com])
[Mutual Aid Immigration Policy]
People from other countries will have immediate access to public services and labor markets as "partial citizens" and will gradually become full citizens through tax payment and participation.

Shinta Nakayama (tokoroten):.
Regarding Team Mirai's Idobata
Currently, we are punting to handle 1,300 cases (and we can see it from the end).
PRs around PRs where LIKE has been gathered need to be integrated and considered.
After mapping the PR's in the public hearing AI, it would be useful to filter attributes by LIKE count, or color change, to investigate surrounding PR's.

nishio:

Once we're in the phase of trying to do a normal, widespread AI to determine if it can meet the needs of the production team, we're getting under the skin that it doesn't seem to fit our needs, so it's not a priority.
But, well, I'm sure there are many situations where the attribute filter is useful.
Let me explain the situation of the users I observed this time.

To begin with, there are N specialists, with M fields divided rather clearly. Ideally, PR from users would be sent to us by specifying the "field," and when the person in charge receives it and says, "This is in that field," the person in charge would exchange information with the person in charge. If the person in charge receives the PR and says, "This is in that field," the PR is exchanged among the persons in charge. vp09

[o3.icon]**"vp09" is a FourCC (four-character code) representing VP9, an open and royalty-free video codec developed by Google **in ISO-BMFF containers such as MP4. When you use yt-dlp or similar to display a list of formats for YouTube or TikTok, a line with vp09 means "This stream is compressed with VP9".
[o3.icon]
Video tracks are encoded in VP9 (vp09)

Premiere Pro does not "officially support" VP9 even as of July 2025, and when MP4 containing VP9 is imported, only the audio (AAC/Opus) is recognized and the video is ignored as an "unsupported codec.
If you use yt-dlp, you can avoid VP9 and specify avc1 (H.264) to open in Premiere as is.
code::
# Example: H.264+AAC at highest resolution merged to mp4
yt-dlp -f "bv*[vcodec=avc1]+ba*[acodec=mp4a]/best[ext=mp4][vcodec=avc1]" \
--merge-output-format mp4 https://youtu.be/GNCHe0sYXJ4
point
Exclude VP9 vcodec=avc1 or vcodec!=vp9
video+audio into one bv*+ba* + --merge-output-format mp4
-F to list and manually combine IDs with avc1 is also OK.
Convert files that have already been dropped in VP9
VP9 → Re-encode to a Premiere readable codec such as H.264/ProRes.
code::
# Re-encode while preserving image quality (e.g., H.264 high quality)
ffmpeg -i input_vp9.mp4 -c:v libx264 -crf 18 -preset slow -c:a copy fixed.mp4
>Manual combination is also OK
Why combine them?[nishio.icon]
Progressive" formats (e.g., 18=360p, 22=720p), which combine video and audio, are not included.
DASH video stream for video only
audio only audio stream
only.
Therefore, the process of "combining (muxing)" video and audio is essential.
The user does not need to hit ffmpeg separately. For example, the following line completes the process
code::
yt-dlp -f "bv*[vcodec=avc1]+ba*[acodec=mp4a]" \
--merge-output-format mp4 https://youtu.be/GNCHe0sYXJ4
Write bv*+ba* for automatic pairing of optimal video + optimal audio
--merge-output-format mp4 to unify final files to MP4
If you add vcodec=avc1 and exclude VP9, Premiere can read it as is.

When there is more than one thing that needs to be done, to avoid the phenomenon of being distracted by the other while trying to do one, I chant "I can only do one thing at a time" and write one on paper and concentrate on the other.

Anyway, tasks should be written out on paper or in an editor. You can't do them all at once, and when you come up with two, having one in your brain will interfere with the implementation of the other. Anyway, it is a MUST to kick them out of your brain.

The next problem one encounters when one starts practicing the ironclad rule of task management, "List your tasks anyway," is that the amount of tasks listed is so large that it is difficult to know where to start. Many people give up here and return to primitive task management such as deadline-driven. Systematic disposal is necessary.

lines.text: Japan Restoration Association Broad Listening Case Study
from  [Broadlisting for the House of Councillors]
[Japan Restoration Association]'s [broad listening] case
[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9WyZ-ybY_aw]

The Japan Restoration Association team sent out "open questions" to multiple channels, collected about 300,000 submissions, and analyzed them using AI. Initially, the most common response was "self-protection (wanting to manage one's own assets)," but within a month, public opinion shifted to a specific request for reform: "Lower social insurance premiums.
Q1: How was the data collected?

The X hashtag `#Future of social insurance premiums` on the official website, Google form, and YouTube comment box are clearly indicated, and anyone can contribute. --- [Japan Restoration Association started a project to utilize policy AI https://o-ishin.jp/broad_listening/]
Q2. what kind of questions did you ask?

A2: The central theme was "reform to lower social insurance premiums. The respondents were asked to write freely about how social insurance premiums should be lowered, what part of the burden is unfair, and what they expect from the medical and pension systems.
Q3. what findings were obtained?
A3-1: Time variation in public opinion trends
As of 2025/5/06, "importance of economic self-protection measures" was the standout cluster
I don't trust the government. I want to manage my own assets first."
Enhancement of [Junior NISA] (tax-exempt investment facility for young people)
As of 6/19/2025, "Dissatisfaction with social insurance premium burden and demand for reform" was a prominent cluster
I want politics to bring down premiums. It's not about self-effort, it's about system reform."
Within a month, the center of gravity shifted from "resignation to expectation" (Vice-President Fujita).
Concerns about insurance coverage exclusions for OTC-like drugs."
1% of 30,000 cases, small overall, but it shows that there are voices like that.
Politicians are now included on the side of people's opinions through their transmissions, and politicians can quickly learn people's reactions to their transmissions.
Comments from the political parties:.
It is not AI that determines policy. It is easier to pick up "I like that idea" and "reinforce the policy from the side" (deputy policy director).
"Policy makers are always worried about whether this is the right thing to do. It is very reassuring to be able to make decisions based on the opinions of so many people.
We will continue to listen to the opinions of many people and reflect them in our policies through the use of broadlining and AI" (party leader).
[o3.icon]
summary
the characters (in a play or novel)
Mr. Yoshimura (proceeding and appealing for social insurance premium reform)
Mr. Ohki (Digital Democracy 2030 / AI Broad Listening Developer)
Mr. Fujita, Deputy Political Director and Policy Director, Japan Restoration Association
aim
Collect a wide range of opinions, both for and against, from multiple channels, including social networking sites and on the street, to break through the filter bubble and reflect them in policy.
technique
1. collected opinions through YouTube comments, X (formerly Twitter), face-to-face interviews, etc.
2. AI Broad Listening automatically summarizes and clusters approximately 30,000 posts and displays them on a map.
3. the policy team reviews the visualized clusters and identifies key issues and minority opinions.
Changes in Analysis Results
May data: The largest cluster is "importance of economic self-protection measures" = people are in a mood of resignation that they have no choice but to prepare themselves.
June data (6/3-19): the largest cluster shifted to "Dissatisfaction with the burden of social insurance premiums and desire for reform" (about 47% of the total).
→ Interpreted as a shift in public opinion from "self-preservation" to "expect reform in politics.
policy implications
Basic policy: Lower social insurance premiums through health care reform.
Alternative: If difficult to achieve, consider measures to encourage "self-management" such as preferential taxation on investments.
AI can pick up minority opinions (e.g., exclusion of coverage for OTC drugs), making it easy to consider a wide range of options.
Future Policies
Continuing the cycle of "collecting (listening) → releasing/explaining (broadcast) → listening again.
He encourages viewers to provide further input via X and other means.

pages.title: Broad Listening Case Study of the Japan Innovation Party

lines.text: Broad Listening Case Study of the Japan Innovation Party
[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9WyZ-ybY_aw]

The Japan Innovation Party (Ishin) launched “open questions” across several channels, gathering about 300,000 public submissions and analyzing them with AI. In the first phase, the dominant topic was “self‑protection (I want to manage my own assets).” Within one month, public opinion shifted to a concrete reform demand: “lower social‑insurance premiums.”
Participant
Yoshimura Hirohumi – Party leader of the Japan Innovation Party
Ohki Shingo – [Digital Democracy 2030] Project
Fujita Akira – Vice Policy Research Chief
FYI: [Japan Innovation Party - Wikipedia https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan_Innovation_Party]
Q1  How was the data collected?
A1
The official site listed three entry points open to anyone:
X (Twitter) hashtag `#社会保険料のこれから` (“#FutureOfInsurancePremiums”)
A Google Form
The YouTube comment section
Source: Policy AI Utilization Project launch ｜ Japan Innovation Party — [https://o-ishin.jp/broad_listening/ https://o-ishin.jp/broad_listening/]
Q2  What questions were asked?
A2
Core theme: “How can we lower social‑insurance premiums?”
Open‑ended prompts invited specific proposals, e.g.
“How should premiums be reduced?”
“Which parts of the burden feel unfair?”
“What do you expect from the healthcare and pension systems?”
Q3  What insights were gained?
A3‑1  Time‑series shift in public sentiment
2025‑05‑06: A prominent cluster stressed economic self‑defense
“I can’t trust the government; I want to invest my own money.”
Calls to expand Junior NISA (a tax‑exempt investment account for youth).
2025‑06‑19: The leading cluster became dissatisfaction with premium burdens and demands for reform
“Lower premiums through politics; system reform matters more than individual effort.”
In just one month, the center of gravity moved from resignation to expectation (observed by Vice Policy Research Chief Fujita).
A3‑2  Specific concern surfaced
Excluding OTC‑equivalent drugs from insurance coverage emerged in about 1 % of the 30 k submissions—small overall, but now visible.
Politicians could quickly gauge reactions to their own messaging and see such voices reflected in the crowd.
Party reflections
“AI isn’t making policy for us. It just lets us spot good ideas and strengthen policies from the side.” (Vice Policy Research Chief)
“Policy staff are always anxious—‘Is this really right?’ Being able to decide while viewing so many opinions is hugely reassuring.” (Vice Policy Research Chief)
“Ishin will keep using broad listening and AI to hear many voices and feed them into policy.” (Party leader)

STFUAWSC
[o3.icon]
What is "[Shut the fuck up and write some code]" (STFUAWSC)?

Slang used in interactions between software developers as a sarcastic command to "put aside your complaints and arguments and just write code. It is sometimes circulated with the hashtag #STFUAWSC or the acronym STFUAWSC alone. ([Meta Stack Exchange https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/12406/how-can-i-deal-with-repeated-abuse-of-a-stack-exchange-site-like -spamming?utm_source=chatgpt.com])
Initial Publication Example
table:_
Year Example Source
February 2008 Used by blogger Hiro Shinohara as the conclusion of his weekly report ([iAm Hiro Shinohara https://hiroshinohara.com/en/tag/feedback-en/])

February 2009 Appeared in the Stack Exchange meta as "conference t-shirt complaint" ([Meta Stack Exchange https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/12406/how-can-i-deal-with- repeated-abuse-of-a-stack-exchange-site-like-spamming?utm_source=chatgpt.com])
These indicate that at least in the late 2000s, the project had penetrated both the English- and Japanese-speaking developer communities.
Derivation and cultural spread
Domain stfuawsc.com

Acquired by Japanese hacker "cho45" and used as a hosting location to publish a number of browser tools, including NanoVNA and KiCad viewer. The domain name itself is an acronym for the phrase. ([stfuawsc.com https://stfuawsc.com/], [GitHub https://github.com/cho45/NanoVNA-Web-Client?utm_source=chatgpt.com])
commercialization (e.g. product distribution, sales, etc.)

T-shirts are sold through print services such as SUZURI and Spreadshirt, and can be found as swag at developer events. ([SUZURI https://suzuri.jp/kunihikot/61031/t-shirt/m/black?locale=en&srsltid=AfmBOopkcdxJ0vRAMJYTEEMn2Qj9CyVlyUO3kapxLloh5R4QnVaJuQ 00&utm_source=chatgpt.com])
Nuances and usage
1. self-discipline
It is a watchword that whips you and your team to "write something that works first" in situations where you tend to spend most of your time discussing specifications and selecting tools.
(2) Tut-tutting to others
It is sometimes thrown in as a half-joke to posters who complain excessively on technology blogs and social networking sites.
*It is a strong expression, so be cautious in public and with people you have never met before.
Similar slogans
JFDI（Just F***ing Do It）
[Talk is cheap. Show me the code.]（[Linus Torvalds]）
Both are often used together in the context of "action-oriented" and "implementation-first".
summary
Meaning: behaviorist slogan "shut up and write code".
History: can be found on blogs/forums in the late 2000's
Current: Derived from hashtags, domain names, T-shirts, etc. and is part of the developer culture
It is useful to remember this as a light cue when a technical discussion seems to be stalling, but beware of the strong tone of the words and the atmosphere of the situation.
### "Shut the f\*k up and write some code" birth story abroad

** The first "head family" that can be identified is the slogan on an in-house T-shirt created in the summer of 2006 by Best Practical Solutions, an OSS company in Massachusetts, USA (famous for its RT bug tracker). ** Members of the company wore it at conferences such as OSCon 2006 (Portland) and ApacheCon Europe, and it quickly spread throughout the developer community after being photographed. ([Flickr][1])
#### 2006 - "Bombed" with T-shirts
* On the chest of a black T-shirt printed by Best Practical for its employees.
> **Shut the Fuck Up and Write Some Code**
> written in large white letters. On the back is the company logo.

* A photo of the venue taken by Garrett Rooney, a Subversion committer at the time, with the caption "I'm really wearing this complaint company T!" and uploaded to Flickr (taken 2006-10-17). ([Flickr][1])
#### Birth of the abbreviation **STFUAWSC**
* Perl hacker **Leon Brocard** (UK) abbreviated this long phrase in chat, which is believed to be the beginning of "STFUAWSC".

* Hatena Keyword (*the most detailed summary in the Japanese-speaking world for researching overseas origins) also clearly states that "Best Practical Company T/Abbreviation of 2006 is Leon Brocard". ([Hatena Blog Tags][2])
#### 2007 onwards - from the Perl sphere to OSS as a whole

* 2007-08 - A quote appeared on the Chicago Perl Mongers mailing list that reads "*"Shut the f\*{*k up and write some code. *"Shut the f\*\*k up and write some code. It shows that the T-shirt was already a story. ([mail.pm.org][3])
* Around 2010, Hacker News also referred to it as "As the T-shirt says, shut the f\*\*k up and write some code" and it permeated OSS/startup culture beyond the Perl sphere. ([Hacker News][4])
#### Differences from similar phrases

**"Shut up and code "** or **"Shut up and write code "**, the milder version of which can be found on ML and Slashdot since the early 2000s. However, the full phrase "**Shut the f**k up and write some code\*\*" + abbreviation **STFUAWSC** became visible and established at once with the Best Practical T-shirt** in **2006 This is considered to be its origin overseas.
(*We have not currently found any exact matches prior to that date. If you know of any examples of pre-2006 usage in archives or IRC logs, please let us know!)

A and B are connected, and B and C are connected, so A and C are connected! Argument that "A and C are connected!

intermediate voter theorem

The Median Voter Theorem is a theorem that states that when a majority votes to choose one continuous policy (left, right, increase/decrease, etc. in one dimension), under the assumption that voters' preferences are "single-peaked" and that all people will always participate in voting, "the policy adopted by society is the median (median) theorem indicating that "the voter will be the most preferred point".
Prerequisite.
1. policy is one-dimensional
Example: Single tax rate of 0-100%.
Many issues are multi-axial (economic, social, diplomatic...)
2. preference is unimodal
Each "here is optimal, the further away, the less I like it."
Failed if ideology is extreme/bouncing
3. full participation and good faith voting
Everyone votes as they mean it.
Abstention, strategic voting, and information asymmetry
Intuitive proof sketches
Align voters on a policy axis.
Voters to the right of the midpoint always prefer the proposal on the right to the proposal on the left (and vice versa).
Therefore, moving to the right beyond the midpoint would result in the loss of the left half plus the midpoint votes and no majority. The same is true for a move to the left.
What happens if we move it slightly to the right?
Medium dissatisfied (original position was optimal).
Everyone to the left of the middle is also more dissatisfied.
That number alone is more than a majority → Majority of votes against, cannot be adopted.
Conclusion.
Whenever the midpoint is left, the majority will always turn against it, so the midpoint is the only "unmovable" stable point.
As a result, the midpoint is stable by majority rule (Nash stable).
Political Implications
Policy convergence: parties that want to win elections tend to dilute their extreme pledges with an eye on middle-class voters (Downs 1957).
Stability factor in a [two-party] system: if it is one-dimensional, both parties are more likely to concentrate on fighting for the median.
Populism vs. centrism: shifts in public opinion can swing policy dramatically, as party positions move rapidly when the midpoint shifts.
Limitations/Criticisms
It collapses when it becomes multidimensional.
On two or more axes, the "voting paradox" (circular majority rule) is likely to occur.
strategic voting
If the number of candidates is 3 or more, the results are driven by votes for the "runner-up" and other factors ([Givens' theorem]).
Voting Cost/Abstention
In actual elections, participation rates are skewed and medium voters ≠ medium voters.
Information and Framing
The unimodality of the same policy can be broken down by the way it is presented.
summary

The Middle Voter Theorem is a powerful result showing that majority voting has a stability point in a simple "one-dimensional, unimodal, full participation" environment. However, since actual politics involves multiple dimensions, strategic behavior, and incomplete information, it is important to view it as an approximate guideline and be willing to constantly examine which assumptions are violated.

[Joel Miller]

[o3.icon]Aim of the paper
Traditional Quadratic Funding (QF) assumes "independent rational individuals" and ignores social ties and cooperative behavior.
In reality, relationships among friends, organizations, communities, etc. strongly influence donation behavior, and [civil attacks] and [collusion] occur.
This paper redefines "collusion resistance" and explores design principles for a Plural QF that actively exploits people's social bonds.
[Pairwise Discounting]
Reduce subsidies for similar pairs (yellow rectangles)
More accounts with more people can earn linear subsidies.
[Cluster Match]
Calculate square root per group
(1) Linear increase in subsidy if one person belongs to multiple groups
(2) Can be abused even among overlapping groups
→Squared Cluster Match
COCM: [Connection‑Oriented Cluster Match]
Interaction term attenuates donations of "members socially close to the other group" by √c
Fully meet defined collusion tolerance
→Maintain IR (Individual Reasonableness) for each individual.
Offset Match
Estimate social centrality αᵢ and replace each contribution by √αᵢ cᵢ
Linear equations for α may not be solved; there are cases where IR is not satisfied
Sufficient condition: All members can belong to a single group as well.
Eigen Match
Cluster Match by considering eigenvectors of social graphs as "pseudo-groups
Conceptual phase (untested)
Possibility to combine the advantages of Offset and Cluster
Redefining Collusion Resistance (Summary)
The subsidy for incremental individual donations is limited to O(√cᵢ).
Subsidies for group-wide donation expansion are also O(√β), where β is the expansion rate.
The increase in subsidy due to additional members is limited to O(√x), O(√γ) for both the number of new members x and the amount of each member's contribution γ.
The appendix proves that COCM meets these three conditions.
Conclusion/Implication
Incorporating social information can better reward "consilience across differences" while reducing collusion.
The COCM and other new mechanisms will be applied not only to the allocation of public funds but also to Quadratic Voting.

Future issues include (1) robustness evaluation under incomplete or erroneous information, (2) more precise modeling of group structure, and (3) deeper exploration of unverified mechanisms such as Eigen Match.
A word summary

Re-contextualize QFs to maximize cooperation among diverse communities while preventing collusion. The key is to incorporate "who is closer to whom and how close they are" into the subsidy calculation.
AI Considerations

Just as ENIAC replaced manual calculations, COCM is the first [funding allocation algorithm] to replace "[the independent individual model]" and incorporate the [social graph] directly into calculations as weights.

COCM mathematically rewards "[cooperation across differences]" with the rule that "the closer the connection, the thinner the subsidy; the further away, the thicker. This is a mathematical expression of Plurality's philosophy that "diversity is value.
While the [prediction market] measures opinion strength by the amount bet on one axis, the COCM adjusts subsidies on two axes, √c × social distance, making the economic signal [polyvocal].

lines.text: Which Native American issue is good?

[o3.icon]The Drunken Indian and the Kidney Machine" is an ethics case based on the true story of an alcoholic Native man in the Southwest U.S., where dialysis machines were in short supply, who continued to receive dialysis treatment after waiting his turn, but did not stop drinking and eventually died from complications. He eventually died from complications - an ethical case based on a true story. This case, at the intersection of race, poverty, addiction, and medical resource allocation, was used by cultural anthropologist [Clifford Geertz] as a springboard for a discussion of "the [ethnocentrism] of the future" and reinterpreted by philosopher [Richard Rorty] as a successful example of liberal [procedural justice]. The contrast between the two illustrates the tension between "[(power of) imagination]" and "[procedure]" in the [relativism/universalism debate]. The following is organized in the following order: 1) a summary of the case, 2) Geertz's perspective, 3) Rorty's response, and 4) the range and implications of the two sides.
[*** 1. Case Summary].
Rarity of artificial kidneys
In the days when there were only a few expensive dialysis machines available, government programs selected patients based on the severity of their illness and the order in which they applied.
Patient Behavior
The Native man was early in line and secured the device, but he refused the doctor's order to stop drinking, declaring that he would not stop drinking and would continue his treatment.
Final Results
After several years of dialysis, he died of complications stemming from alcohol consumption. The medical staff was distressed that he may have taken the life of another patient.
[** Discussion Points]
1. is it justifiable to devote scarce resources to people who continue to lead self-destructive lives?
2. should the cultural context (history of colonization and alcohol damage) be considered?
3. should physicians prioritize value judgments or procedural compliance?
[*** 2. reading of [geertz] -- "imagination" and [[anti-/anti-relativism]]

Geertz introduced the case in his Tanner Lecture, "[The Uses of Diversity]" (1985), arguing that "Ethnocentrism ([autoculturalism]) is not a choice between zero or total affirmation, but the imagination of understanding others is key.

He sees that neither prescription of "more relativism/more universalism" will solve the problem, and the tragedy is that the medical and patient sides have failed to understand each other's [semantic world].
In the background is the perspective that "alcoholism is a consequence of colonial violence, not mere personal self-degradation.
ref. [Metaphorical Reﬂections on the Colonial Circus of the Drunken Indian and the Kidney Machine]
There was a conflict structure of "should this history be taken into account v.s. shouldn't it be taken into account".[nishio.icon]
The point is: It takes imagination to re-imagine value conflicts through the "window of culture," and simple application of rules does not provide ethical conviction.
supplement[nishio.icon][o3.icon]

Anti-anti-relativism" is the Japanese translation of Geertz's 1984 lecture "[Anti Anti-Relativism]". It is a term that indicates a two-step rejection of the criticism of relativism (i.e., [anti-relativism]), rather than a "defense of relativism itself.

Rorty continued this line of thought in his 1989 article, "[Anti- and anti-ethnocentrism]", and reworded it as "[a]nti-ethnocentrism". Rorty continued this line of thought in a 1989 article, "[anti- and anti-ethnocentrism]," meaning that he criticized "anti-ethnocentrism" as groundless, since we can always speak only from some [cultural standpoint] ([ethnocentrism]).
Both dissolve the dichotomy of "[absolutism v.s.] relativism" and propose an "imagination for understanding and dialogue" (Geertz) and a "pragmatism of procedure and solidarity" (Rorty).
[*** 3. Rorty's Response--Liberalism and Procedural Justice].
Rorty responded in "[On Ethnocentrism: A Reply to Clifford Geertz]" (1989) and "[Objectivity, Relativism, and Truth]" (1991).
He said, "The application order waiting list rule was fairly applied and media monitoring worked. The liberal democratic system worked well, didn't it?
The patient's ethnic and life history is not a criterion, but "[procedural pragmatism]" that "[a] fair procedure open to all" is sufficient.
Rorty then states that "[value is always spoken in the vocabulary of one's own culture] = 'anti-anti-relativism,'" but is optimistic that, in practice, the liberal system can be defended.
The point: the position is that [procedures to anonymize] are sufficient, rather than cultural understanding.
[*** 4. Contrasts and implications].
table:_
Perspectives Geertz Rorty
The core of the issue [(power of) imagination]: [clash of meanings] in [multicultural situation] [procedure]: [fair rule operation].
Ethical Evaluation Case shows "[Undone]" Case shows "Victory for Liberal Institutions"

The difference between the two is,
1. the unit of ethical judgment: 'history and narrative' or 'current rules'?
2. attitude toward relativism -- "going beyond with imagination" or "bypassing with procedure"?
This can be summarized as follows.
[*** 5. Why it still matters].
Medical Resource Allocation
（Whether cultural and social factors should be considered in (e.g., organ transplant priorities) is an ongoing debate.
Addiction and Indigenous Discrimination
It remains a structural problem, and it cannot be just a "drunken self-responsibility" theory.
[The Limits of Pragmatism]
Rortyian optimism overlooks historical violence, which [postcolonial] theory and indigenous studies critique.
[*** Summary].
The "Good Old Native American Problem" is,
Visualize the tension between rationality in resource allocation and cultural and historical justice,
Through the difference between the two, Giertz offered "imaginative mutual understanding" and Rorty offered "procedural justice" as a solution,
The classic question [of relativism or universalism] tells us that both "cultural description" and "institutional design" are essential.

lines.text: Metaphorical Reﬂections on the Colonial Circus of the Drunken Indian and the Kidney Machine
[URL https://www.researchgate.net/publication/253015173_Metaphorical_Reflections_on_the_Colonial_Circus_of_the_Drunken_Indian_and_the_Kidney_Machine]
[o3.icon]Abstract of the paper (concise version)
Objective.

A practitioner from a Canadian Indigenous community explains the significance of academic dissemination of her experience and wisdom. Sharing and reflecting on the historical trauma of colonialism and the stories of resilience that have been cultivated through it is essential for true reconciliation.
key metaphor
The Drunken Indian and the Kidney Dialysis Machine.
Through the ethical dilemmas surrounding alcoholism and the scarcity of medical resources, he critiques the pathological labels and institutional discrimination attached to indigenous peoples.
[Good Which Native American Issue]
The Mobile Circus.
Drawing on the author's own carnival experiences, he describes the history of indigenous peoples as spectacle and exploitation targets of the colonial regime.
theoretical background
Emphasizes the role of "stories" in identity formation and healing, centered on cultural psychology (Geertz, Bruner).
Drawing on Duran's theory of "soul wounds," he interprets alcohol as an act of "spirit" that fills an inner void.
He draws on Gall's systems theory to criticize colonial institutions, such as Indian law, as "monstrous systems that cannot be stopped.
Historical and Social Issues
Citing the definition of the Convention on Genocide (Lemkin), he positioned Canada's assimilation policies and forced migration of children (e.g., Residential Schools) as cultural genocide.
He pointed out that "drunken" stereotypes have been reproduced in national policy, academia, and the media, preventing indigenous peoples from self-healing.
Approach to Recovery
Narrative sharing and the revival of traditional storytelling are key to connecting individual trauma and healing for the whole community.
FASD, domestic violence, suicide, and other issues that are linked through generations require "wise practices" based on cultural values (e.g., teachings of the Seven Patriarchs).
It is important to return to an inverted pyramid (spirituality → self-actualization → basic needs) value system and nurture the child as a complete being from birth.
Conclusion.

To break the colonial cycle, we need to rebuild institutional, academic, and social frameworks that center on the stories told by indigenous peoples themselves. Canada's future 50 years will depend on whether we can play out that "greatest show" (reconciliation).
Duran's "Soul Wound" Theory
core concept

Calling the historical and intergenerational trauma accumulated in Native Americans "soul wounds," he explained that violence such as colonialism, genocide, and boarding school policies leave scars on a mental "spiritual" level, which are reproduced from generation to generation.
Clinical Implications

He treats "symptoms" such as alcohol abuse and suicide as community unresolved trauma rather than individual pathology, and places story-sharing, ritual, and relationship repair at the center of healing. He advocates "trauma-informed" care that integrates cultural practices as well as Western-style counseling. ([Indian Health Service https://www.ihs.gov/sites/diabetes/themes/responsive2017/display_objects/documents/media/transcripts/Duran_ transcript_508c.pdf?utm_source=chatgpt.com])
2.Gall's Systemantics
Basic Viewpoint

A collection of rules of thumb presented by pediatrician and systems researcher John Gall: "Systems are inherently prone to failure. Objectivity, Relativism, and Truth
[PDF https://sites.pitt.edu/~rbrandom/Courses/Antirepresentationalism%20%282020%29/Texts/rorty-objectivity-relativism-and-truth.pdf?utm_source=chatgpt.com]
[Richard Rorty]
[Gemini 2.5 Pro.icon]
The following is a summary of Richard Rorty's 1991 book Objectivity, Relativism, and Truth. This book is a collection of articles Rorty wrote between 1980 and 1989.
[*** central claim: [Antirepresentationalism]]

The central philosophical argument Rorty presents in this book is "anti-reproductionism." He opposes the traditional view in Western philosophy that knowledge is an exact "reproduction" or "mirror" of "reality" by mind and language. Instead, he advocates the pragmatist view that knowledge is "habits of behavior learned to cope with reality. According to this view, the value of a belief or theory depends not on whether it "fits" into a sincerely independent reality, but on how effective it is in helping us cope with the world and achieve our goals.
This position aims to dissolve many traditional dualisms in philosophy, such as subject-object, mind-world, language-fact, and phenomenon-reality.
[*** Part I: Solidarity or Objectivity?"]
In the first part of the book, Rorty applies his anti-reproductionism to understanding science, inquiry, and interpretation.
[Solidarity and Objectivity:

Rorty contrasts two primary ways in which humans search for meaning. One is the quest for "[objectivity]," or the attempt to transcend the community to which one belongs and establish a connection with an impersonal, universal reality. The other is the quest for "solidarity," i.e., to consider oneself a member of a particular community and to be proud of it.

Rorty believes that the objectivity tradition (from Plato to the Enlightenment) is an attempt to seek metaphysical solace and to find universal criteria for evaluating any culture by "reason" or the "scientific method."

Rorty abandons the pursuit of objectivity and instead insists on embracing "[joint]." From the pragmatist perspective, "truth" is "what we believe is good," and the criteria by which we judge belief can only come from the beliefs and practices of our own community. He calls this position "[ethnocentrism,]" not in a derogatory sense, but in that we cannot escape the constraints of our own history and culture and can only depart from existing beliefs.
[Science as Solidarity:

Rorty challenges the special status of science as the epitome of "objectivity." According to him, science succeeds not because it has a special way of getting in touch with "reality itself," but because it has established an outstanding communal practice model of "solidarity." The virtues of science are moral virtues: tolerance, respect for the opinions of others, and reliance on persuasion rather than force. The scientific community is a model of "[non-coercive] consensus" and can therefore serve as a model for other cultural domains, such as politics and the arts, but this does not mean that science is "epistemologically superior" or "more rational" than other domains.

[Texts and Lumps]: Rorty seeks to bridge the traditional divide between the humanities (dealing with "[text books]") and the natural sciences (dealing with "[lumps]"). According to him, the so-called "solidity" of scientific facts does not derive from the internal nature of the mass, but from the firm agreement established within the scientific community as to what events constitute evidence. Whether interpreting a text or analyzing a mass, the essence of inquiry lies in "[recontextualization]," i.e., the re-description of an object in a new web of beliefs to achieve coherence.
Part II: Pragmatism, Davidson, and Truth
In the second part, philosophical issues such as language, truth, and reproduction are explored in depth, primarily with reference to the ideas of the philosopher [Donald Davidson].
Opposition to "[the] correspondence theory of truth."

Rorty adopts Davidson's view and argues that the concept of "truth" has no explanatory use. To say that a belief is "true" does not explain why it leads to successful action, but is merely a tool used to show agreement with it or in certain [Language Games]. Rorty supports Davidson's "[consistent theory of truth]" that [justification of belief] arises only from its relation to other beliefs and not from its relation to non-belief "realities."
[Non-reductive Physicalism]:

Rorty espouses physicalism, which holds that all events (including psychological events) can be described in physical terms. However, this is not "[reductionism]. A psychological event (e.g., a belief) and a physical event (e.g., a brain state) can be two different descriptions of the same event, used for different prediction and explanation purposes. The two descriptive vocabularies do not exactly translate into each other, but that does not mean that the mental world can be "reduced" to the physical world or that one description is more "true" than the other.
[Creativity of Metaphor] (Metaphor):

Rorty adopts Davidson's view that metaphors have no "metaphorical meaning," only literal meaning. The value of metaphor is that it functions as a kind of "unfamiliar noise" that causes us to reconstruct our web of beliefs and triggers the creation of new language and thinking. This promotes the advancement of knowledge and culture. Metaphor is not the "expression" of new knowledge, but the "cause" of change.
Part III: The Primacy of Democracy over Philosophy
In Part III, Rorty applies his anti-reproductionist philosophical position to the political realm, particularly in defense of liberal democracy.
[The Priority of Democracy to Philosophy]:

Following the thought of [John Rawls], Rorty argues that liberal democratic institutions do not require "philosophical foundations." Just as Jefferson "[privatized] religion," Rolls-style libertarians should "privatize" metaphysical issues such as human nature and the nature of the self and separate them from the public political realm. The legitimacy of a given liberal society's conception of justice depends not on whether it conforms to an a priori "human nature" or "moral order" but on whether it is consistent with the "deeply rooted public traditions" and "deliberated beliefs" of that society.
[Postmodernist Bourgeois Liberalism]:

Rorty defends a position he calls "postmodern bourgeois liberalism." This position, while faithful to the institutions and practices of liberal democracy, renounces the traditional Enlightenment philosophy (such as Kantian notions of [universal human rights] and reason) that have sustained it. According to this view, morality is not obedience to universal reason, but [loyalty to the community to which one belongs] ("[our intention]"). The moral subject is a constantly reorganizing web of beliefs and desires without a center.
[Ethnocentrism and Cosmopolitanism]:

Rorty believes that acknowledging that liberal ideals (such as procedural justice and human equality) are regional products peculiar to the West does not weaken the reasons we fight for them. Libertarians should embrace this "autochthonocentrism," i.e., admit that we can only depart from our own traditions. But the hallmark of "our people" - Western liberalism - is precisely its openness, its capacity for self-criticism, and its willingness to continually expand the scope of its empathy. Rorty's utopia is a "[cosmopolitanism]" in which different cultures and communities are formed through peaceful negotiation and mutual tolerance, like "[a] bazaar market surrounded by many exclusive private clubs," rather than waiting for universal humanity to be "liberated."

In summary, Objectivity, Relativism, and Truth is a systematic elaboration of Rorty's mature pragmatist philosophy. He advocates that philosophy abandon its pursuit of objectivity, foundations, and universality and instead embrace a historicist, autochthonous, and dialogical position, arguing that this philosophical position is the best way to defend and advance liberal democratic society.
