pages.title: OSS Product Continuity Mechanism with Blender as an example

lines.text: OSS Product Continuity Mechanism with Blender as an example
The [OSS] product [continuity] mechanism with [Blender] as an example
[o3.icon]
## OSS Product Continuity Mechanism with Blender as an example
### 1. history - foundation of continuity starting with "Free Blender

* In 2002, NaN, the developer of the commercial version of Blender, went bankrupt. Founder Ton Roosendaal negotiated with investors for 100,000 € to buy back the source code and trademark, and together with the community launched a crowdfunding **"Free Blender "** campaign. The goal was reached in just 7 weeks, and the GPL release was the starting point for the current OSS regime ([docs.blender.org][1]).
### 2. Governance Structure
| Organization | Role | Contribution to Continuity
| Corporate identity, trademark management, and donation recipients | Neutrality and trust
| Hiring of core developers, maintenance of LTS build docs, open movie production | Stable employment of full time developers / verification of new features
| Clearly define code owner and manage review and roadmap per module | Prevent knowledge concentration and bus coefficient↑ ([blender.org][2])
### 3. funding model
| Major Inflows | Mechanisms | Latest Scale

| **Monthly Donations Development Fund** | Individuals and Corporate Subscriptions | Approximately **255,000 USD** per month, 7 575 individual accounts and 38 corporate accounts (as of 2025-07) ([Blender Development Fund][3])

**Corporate Membership (Bronze 6k€ → Patron 240k€)** Privileges include name listing, development contact, etc. | Hierarchical design allows diverse companies to participate ([Blender Development Fund][4])
| **Blender Studio Subs / Merchandise Sales** | Open Movie Materials & Tutorials | Additional Financial Resources for Hiring Developers
| **Grants and Lump Sum Donations** | Epic MegaGrant, etc. | Risk Diversification |

> Total annual donations rose steadily from 2.17 M in 2022 to 2.55 M in 2023 to 2.93 M USD in 2024 ([Reddit][5]), and the Foundation's annual report also reported income of 2.5 M € in 2023, +20 % over the previous year ([download.blender.org][6]).
### 4. release strategy
**Quarterly release**: Normal version approximately every 4 months.
**Annual LTS**: 1 copy each year for 2 years maintenance. Example: 4.2 LTS (2024-07-16) ([blender.org][7]), **Latest stable version 4.5 LTS (2025-07-15)** ([blender.org][2 ]]).
* Clear calendar ensures reliability as a business tool for users.
### 5. community and ecosystem
**Code Contribution**: Modularity + RFC/Code Review for both quality and speed.
**Add-on market**: Allows commercial sales on external sites while maintaining GPL compatibility. The economic sphere of the ecosystem attracts developers.
**Open Movie**: Test new features in production and release the results free of charge. Combination of marketing and QA.
### 6. Factors supporting continuity
1.**Community-driven "ownership" feeling**.
* The sense of party that supported the "buyback" in the early days still remains as a culture of donation.
2.**Multi-tiered revenue structure**.
* Small donations + corporate members + production studio + merchandise to avoid "single sponsor dependence.
3.**Neutral governance**.
* The separation of the foundation and the trademark ensures that it is not overly dependent on any one company.
4.**Product management transparency**.
* Clear public roadmap, agenda, and release cycle, making it easy to plan for long-term use.
5.**Consistent investment in user value**.
* Priority allocation of funds to UX improvements and LTS maintenance, eliminating "it's free, so I'm worried.
### 7. OSS Product Continuity Tips (What we can learn from Blender)
**Make the funding source "marquetry "**: Broaden the base of small amounts while offering a clear quid pro quo to major sponsors.
**Make governance transparent**: Document authority and responsibilities and provide mechanisms for community oversight.
**"Eat" in real projects **: Speed up the improvement cycle by creating your own production examples using OSS, like Blender Studio.
**Provide a long-term support version**: Create an environment where business users can invest with confidence.
**Brand and Story**: Free Blender's story still provides "a reason to donate".

Blender is a good example of a company that has continued to evolve its product for over 20 years by building a clear governance and multi-tiered revenue model starting from "software bought back by the community". If you want to turn your product into OSS, the key to sustainability is to design a set of **funding, governance, and release strategies**.
[1]: https://docs.blender.org/api/htmlI/x115.html?utm_source=chatgpt.com "Blender's History"
[2]: https://developer.blender.org/docs/release_notes/ "Blender Release Notes - Blender Developer Documentation"
[3]: https://fund.blender.org/ "Blender Development Fund"
[4]: https://fund.blender.org/corporate-memberships/ "Corporate Memberships — Blender Development Fund"
[5]: https://www.reddit.com/r/blender/comments/1huo9nw/regarding_the_recent_news_about_blender_lack_of/?utm_source=chatgpt.com "Regarding the recent news about Blender lack of funding, I made ..."
[6]: https://download.blender.org/foundation/Blender-Foundation-Annual-Report-2023.pdf?utm_source=chatgpt.com "[PDF] Blender Annual Report — 2023"
[7]: https://developer.blender.org/docs/release_notes/4.2/?utm_source=chatgpt.com "Blender 4.2 LTS Release Notes - Blender Developer Documentation"

lines.text: Allow every person to have multiple affiliations
As one of the concrete directions of "No one is left behind.
Allow every person to have multiple affiliations."
I thought of a
Zero affiliation is loneliness.
We want to create a state where everyone has at least one affiliation to start with.
In the past, people belonged to "villages" and other local communities without choice.
Urbanization, individualism, living alone, and other lifestyle changes have resulted in more people not being able to join the community and being left behind
We want to create an opportunity for them to join at least one community first.
The next step in this process should not be a single community.
When you are kicked out of that community, you return to the "loneliness of not belonging to a community," so blind faith and dependence arise to avoid being kicked out.
Just like cults give lonely people a "sense of belonging" and take them in.
Multiple community affiliations to help you stay away from the "crazy community".

pages.title: What happened with the "new section on Advancing the Human Rights Situation?"

lines.text: What happened with the "new section on Advancing the Human Rights Situation?"

Among the PRs of [initiative taken by the government in the formulation of a policy or bill (rather than by bureaucrats) to promote good governance], only one PR received over 100 comments at most. of the 10 or so comments at most, only one received more than 100 comments.
[o3.icon]

The following is a report on why PR 6335 "Establishment of a new section on the advancement of the human rights situation" has become a "hot topic" in a short period of time, based on publicly available information. To summarize just the main points: (1) The proposal included a large amount of highly abstract information on "human rights," a topic that involves a high degree of value judgment, and received criticism from both legal and technical experts at the same time. (2) Before the rules for discussion on GitHub were in place, the number of comments from outside parties increased, and the comments snowballed from the first day. --The result was a three-tiered structure.
[nishio.icon]

In short, it is an understanding that this is what happens when a highly abstract discussion is posted in a place that is not supposed to be a discussion forum, and then spread on social networking sites.
(Personally, I think it would have been good to move to PUBLIC ARCHIVE at the end of the Upper House election.)
Team Mirai staff did not participate in this discussion, so calling this an "internal Team Mirai discussion" is misinformation.
If you put something on a bulletin board that anyone can write on, it's like a third-party fight broke out there.

Note as an example of the failure of a large scale deliberation (well, I didn't expect to start a discussion there, so it was just a web forum without an AI moderator like the one I had put in during the Tokyo gubernatorial election, so it was vulnerable, I guess).
Continuation of o3 description
1. the content of PR and the specific fire of the "technology party
1-1 Outline of Proposal
Through a dialogue between the proposer (Akio Hoshi) and an AI chatbot, he tried to add a new section to the manifesto called "Advancement of the Human Rights Situation"

Criticisms of "jurisprudential imprecision" and "loss of intellectual property in redefinition" erupted because of the ambiguous connection between human rights and international and domestic law, while positioning human rights as "norms".
1-2 Direct causes of the stormy discussion
Major Points of Controversy Examples of Typical Comments
Treatment of enforceability of international human rights law and Article 98 of the Constitution "Japan has not ceded its authority to the UN", etc.
Engineering users: Implementation should be prioritized over "norms"; language is abstract; "Moving code is as good as police power", etc.
Philosophy/Humanities Users: The redefinition of the concept of human rights, History of Enlightenment thought "Misunderstanding the flow from Magna Carta," etc.
Thus, July 14 → over 100 comments as of July 24, an unusually long time even for the party's repository!
2. diffusion dynamics - "X influencer cannon
2-1 Diffusion time line
| Around 20:00 on 7/14 | Create PR → Start discussion in GitHub
| 7/15 am | Post by Akio Hoshi (IT x Human Rights Journalist) with link to X
| Retweeted by author Taiyo Fujii on July 15, the same day
| 7/15 evening | Researcher Sayaka Oki described the thread as a "dangerous discussion" |
| Reprinted in Threads and Bluesky
| 7/18-19 | note.com and other outside media review articles
2-2 Impact
Hoshi's post received 12,000 likes and over 3,000 reposts (from a report with screenshots), and the number of new visitors to GitHub PR skyrocketed.
Technical clusters with overlapping social graphs flowed in at once, and the "anyone can write" mechanism made the volume of discussion uncontrollable.
In the GitHub comment section, the "discuss here instead of X" and "explain in X" groups clashed, and the meta-discussion accelerated.
3. secondary wave: media and critics' arguments
note The article "Selectivism and Dystopia" makes the debate more visible by mentioning the danger of a controlled society while the proposal calls for "inclusion of the weak.
The position of "Team Mirai = Tech x Human Rights" was reexamined on YouTube political feeds and blogs, and began to spill over into the party image.
4. summary - three reasons for the expansion of the problem
Difficulty in setting the theme
The cost of shared assumptions is high due to the intersection of jurisprudence, ethics, and implementation.
Vulnerability of Open Draft Method
The operational rules that made GitHub a "plaza" were not yet in place and could not withstand the surge of inbound traffic.
External pressure through influencer diffusion

Tens of thousands of reaches were reached overnight, and participants with varying degrees of understanding, both inside and outside the party, commented simultaneously. As a result, discussions diverged on multiple topics, including "What are human rights?" and "What is the boundary between politics and code?

This case is a typical example of the combination of difficulty of the content itself, social proliferation, and immaturity in process design, which resulted in a short period of time in which the situation could not be resolved.

display
Regarding the smartphone view, still concerned about the issue of poor default appearance when real users post on social networking sites.
I thought it would be difficult to solve the problem drastically and left it until now, but now I have an idea of "share while zoomed", which is implementable and could solve the problem so-so.

In other words, "Since it is impossible to set the default to show the entire screen in smartphone view, it would be better to be able to decide where to show the screen as the initial screen when in smartphone view".

I would like to be able to display the "original data before extraction" in a similar way to turning on "link" (X prohibits redistribution, so this is disabled, but there are times when I want to see the original data without a link if I want to insert and analyze data that is not so redistributed).
I'd prefer "click for modal view."
Interesting scatter plots embedded in news sites: [Asahi Shimbun Broad Listening].
Certainly there is a need to embed it in your own system for ease of use as a news site.
Convenience of management
Team Mirai's admin screen, 61 reports, hard to scroll through, I want the newly created one to be on top (just a thought note).
I think you will want to organize it in some way when multiple departments start using it (maybe add tags and a screen to filter by tags).
There was a problem with the default prompt to extract "opinion", which targeted the question text but extracted opinions.
Now that I have a more concrete example of the abstract "we need to change the prompts depending on the situation," I'll put it into language.
I want to extract only the "criticism" from X's post and observe
I want to extract only the "sense of the problem" (what the proposer feels is the problem) from the policy pull requests.
I want to extract only "questions" from the questions to AI Anne's ("Great! and so on are removed)
At the moment, I'm tweaking the prompts, but I think it would be better to have a support tool since it's quite a hassle to change the "fewshot example" to match the prompts.
Rather than having users directly use the support tool itself, it would be easier for them to select a few typical use cases as presets based on my trial-and-error experience.

The form to set the number of clusters will probably use onChange to validate, but if you try to change 20 to 12, for example, it will be modified to 2 when you enter 1, making it difficult to enter the number of clusters, so I think onBlur or something similar would be better.
https://github.com/digitaldemocracy2030/kouchou-ai/issues/640
Automation of report generation with API

It is easy for non-engineers to set it up on the admin screen, but honestly, as an engineer, when I do a lot of work, I would want to send JSON to the API to start the process (not an official means, but it seems possible if you read the code).
The script to run X posts for 5 days on the spread AI one day at a time ran through successfully.
It's messy, but I'll share it with you.
https://gist.github.com/nishio/dac10b1316e6a984eb37a1360926040b

I haven't published the report yet, but I can see that when we released AI An, people were excited about the 24-hour support. I think it would be a good idea to do a daily analysis with GitHub Actions, so that it can be used for people who are in situations where they want to watch a large number of social networking posts.
[Notify me when a report is complete - Issue #641 - digitaldemocracy2030/kouchou-ai https://github.com/digitaldemocracy2030/kouchou-ai/issues/641]
Later editing
I want to edit the slug as well as the title and description.
You want to clean up the URL when you publish it, not when you preview it internally.
Hesitant to make a clean URL for public use because of the possibility of changing parameters for review during the internal preview phase.
validation problem
In some cases, the report generation screen completes normally, but when a report is opened, a 500 Error occurs.
Reproduced twice with the same data.
This was the first case where I tried an attributed analysis, so I changed to a CSV with the attribute field removed and it didn't reproduce.
There could be a problem around attribute analysis, but I don't have time to debug that right now, so I'll think about it after the election.

Think of society as a human computation

Our society can be viewed as a huge computational process in which countless human elements interact and make decisions. In the past, the calculations were carried out by the unique activities of humans, such as institutional design, debate, and negotiation. However, with the advent of computers that far surpass human computation and the recent emergence of large-scale language models (LLM), the nature of this "social computation" is about to change fundamentally. This paper examines how technology has changed the structure of social computation and where it is headed in the future through two opposing paradigms.
The Dawn of Computing: Substituting and Extending Human Computational Capabilities

As the name "computing thing" implies, the early history of computers has been a process of replacing and extending human computing power. ENIAC, developed during World War II to calculate artillery shell trajectories for the U.S. Army, is a symbolic example of the mechanization of the manual labor of female computationalists, who until then were called "computers. Initially, computing power was directly related to military power.

Its power was also used for peaceful purposes: the 1880 U.S. Census, which took about eight years to tabulate, was completed in less than a year in 1890, thanks to a punch-card tabulator invented by Herman Hollerith. This technology, which later led to IBM, supported governments and large corporations that required large amounts of tabulation work. This was an early form of "social computation," the gathering and computing of large amounts of information from society. The innovation of the punch card encoded society's information into a machine-readable format and dramatically increased IO (input/output) bandwidth.

Viewed in terms of this "information input from society," the modern electoral system appears to be a very archaic system. It is, as Audrey Tan points out, nothing more than "a slow communication that sends five bits of information once every four years." The digital native generation, accustomed to texting on social networking sites, will not be satisfied with this slow and low-bandwidth communication.
Shift in computational paradigm: from rule-based to weighted models

A major shift also occurred in the design philosophy of the very programs responsible for society's calculations. Early computer programming was dominated by the "logical block paradigm," represented by the "if statement," in which humans piled up logical rules. This became widely popular because it was easy to produce value even on poor computing machines.

However, as data and computational power grow, this paradigm reaches its limits. The decisive turning point was the overwhelming victory of "AlexNet" in the 2012 image recognition contest (ILSVRC-2012). This was the moment when rule-based methods, in which humans manually design features, were completely defeated by neural networks that learn weights from large amounts of data (the weighting paradigm). This shift in values from "learning from data rather than designing features" spilled over into the world of language. Rather than approaches based on human-defined "words" and "grammar" rules, statistical model-based approaches were shown to improve the performance of machine translation and other applications.

At the forefront of this trend is the large-scale language model (LLM), which has reached the level of university student-level language proficiency. LLMs are dramatically lowering the cost of communication between humans and between humans and computers, and are changing the very infrastructure of society.
A fork in the road to the future: Hum-Free or Plurality?
As of 2025, when LLMs and smart contracts (programmable contract enforcement technology) will simultaneously become widespread, the future of social computation is diverging in two major directions.

One is the direction of thinking that humans are no longer needed in the calculation process, but rather that their intervention is an "overhead" that reduces speed and efficiency. While this ideology prioritizes the purity and speed of calculation, it runs the risk of losing sight of the purpose of what and for whom is being calculated. Like the anecdote of Thales, who fell into a well while walking while looking at a distant star, we may lose sight of the reality beneath our feet in pursuit of only the ideal. Even if a time will come when human intelligence will be inferior to that of computers in the long run, this does not directly lead to the conclusion that humans should give up the steering wheel right now.

The other is the concept of "plurality" proposed by Audrey Tan and others. This is "technology that allows diverse people to work together to get things done," and is based on the idea that new value is created when different things are combined. In this approach, technology is used not to replace people, but to reduce the cost of people "bringing" their wisdom.
As specific social calculation mechanisms to realize Plurality, two main approaches are being explored: "language" and "money (incentives)".
Language Aspects: Broadlistening

This is a technology that assists AI in helping one person to listen to and understand the essence of the opinions of a vast number of people. Traditionally, "broadcasting," in which one person speaks to many, has been technically easy, but the reverse has been difficult due to the limitations of human cognitive abilities. The development of LLM summarization technology has made this possible, and even [Global Deliberations] is now within sight. This will make it easier for diverse voices that have been buried until now to be reflected in policy making and other processes.
Money (incentive) aspect: Predictive markets and programmable empowerment

Another promising social calculation is the [prediction market]. This is a system in which people bet money on future events to aggregate collective knowledge and obtain highly accurate predictions. On social networking sites, "extreme words" attract attention, but on prediction markets, "the amount of money wagered" becomes the strength of opinion, encouraging more dispassionate judgments. Polymarket, one of the world's largest prediction markets, has shown that Ethereum's smart contract technology allows large markets to function without a centralized administrator.

This is largely due to the existence of Ethereum, a "general-purpose computer that can compute common content while being globally distributed," which began operating in 2015. This has made it possible to automate and make transparent the execution of contracts and delegation of authority through code.
Conclusion: Beyond Optimization to Society as a Dynamic Computation

When we view society as a human computation, we are at a historical turning point. That is, the "dramatic reduction of language friction" through LLMs and the "programmability of delegation of authority" through smart contracts are simultaneously underway.

What kind of society should we design on this new computational infrastructure? It is not an optimization calculation toward a single objective function. Rather, it is a dynamic process in which diverse entities meet, create new combinations, and constantly rewrite the structure of the calculation itself. The economy stabilizing and reaching equilibrium may no longer mean "recession," as Schumpeter pointed out.

AI and smart contracts are powerful computational tools, but the "problem-setting" itself, what to compute and what kind of social structure to aim for, is still a human role. Our future should not be filled with a single voice. Plurality's vision of the future is a society where diverse voices resonate with each other and continue to co-create new values.

The perspective that "society is a human computation" provides a powerful lens through which to understand our times. But we are not just experiencing an increase in computing speed or a change in tools. The very operating system (OS) of society itself is undergoing a fundamental architectural shift. It is a shift from an explicitly human-designed** "rule-based society" to a "weight-based society "** that is dynamically tuned by myriad interactions.
1. social OS upgrade: from code to executable code

Society has been driven by **"static rulebooks "** such as constitutions, laws, and corporate rules. This is very similar to the "logical block paradigm," or programs described by chains of "if-then" statements in the history of computers [From if statements to machine learning]. This paradigm was good at drawing clear boundaries, but it was fragile in the face of complex and unpredictable realities, and required a huge amount of exception handling and bureaucratic patchwork. With the slow, multi-year feedback of elections [Elections are slow communications, sending 5 bits every four years.], updates to this OS were hopelessly outpaced.
Now we have the building blocks of a new operating system.

Broad listening as a high-bandwidth input layer: LLM-enabled [broad listening] is more than just an opinion aggregation tool. It is a new I/O port for society that re-maps the public will, previously compressed into a few-bit scalar value called "votes," into a high-dimensional vector space. For the first time, the "dense" data of people's diverse values, concerns, and hopes become computable inputs in real time.

Prediction Markets and Smart Contracts as Sociophysical Engines: mechanisms like [prediction markets] and Quadratic Funding act as the new CPUs of society. They are engines that give **"weights "** to the higher-dimensional values (Beliefs and Values) mapped by broad listening - "how strongly believed" and "how much resources are worth investing" - and project them into concrete resource allocations. A "global calculator" like Ethereum [a general-purpose calculator that can compute common content while being globally distributed] ensures that this engine works based on code (verifiability), not trust (trust).

The combination of the two transforms social rules from "a code that is difficult to amend once established" to "an executable code whose parameters are constantly updated by the data flow of the real world.
2. new division of labor between humans and machines: from a computational resource to a source of value

On top of this new operating system, the role of humans will also be radically redefined. We are no longer the bottleneck of the computational process, much less the CPU. Our value is not in the efficiency of the computation, but in standing "outside" of it.

Humans supply "value mutations": AI is good at deriving optimal solutions from existing data, but it cannot create entirely new questions or values that do not exist in the data set, i.e., the "assumptions of computation itself". The role of humans is to inject elements outside of computation, such as irrational passion, ethical hesitation, and unexpected curiosity, into the system to serve as "disturbers" that prevent the system from falling into local minima (locally optimal solutions). We are the source of unpredictable mutations in the evolutionary computational algorithm that is society.

Humans are sensors of "qualia" (qualitative senses): happiness, despair, trust, beauty. These subjective experiences, while extremely difficult to datameterize, are the root of the values to which human society aspires. Humans in the new operating system will function as countless sensors spread across the ends of society, collecting these "qualia" that are difficult to verbalize and quantify, and will play a role in enriching the objective function of the system itself.
No longer is man's job to be "smart," but to be human itself.
(This is not my opinion, but I'll think about it later[nishio.icon])
3. the dangers of the new OS: tyranny of the interface and the seamlessness trap
However, the transition to a "weight-based society" also creates new challenges.

Tyranny of the interface: how we express our opinions (Broad Listening UI) and how we express our values (Quadratic Voting UI) all depend on the interface. The design of this interface may subconsciously guide our thoughts and actions. Just as clergy once monopolized the word of God, in the future there is a danger that UI/UX designers will become the "new gatekeepers" controlling access to the will of the people.

The seamlessness trap: What do we lose when the cost of consensus-building is reduced to near zero and all social friction is "smoothed" by technology? The process of painful debate and confrontation served in itself to strengthen community cohesion and flex social muscles to overcome easy conclusions. A society that is too smooth may show fragility when faced with difficult challenges.
(I get the feeling that the storyline here is influenced by [a culture that approves of dialectical development] [nishio.icon])
Conclusion: From "answers" that should be calculated to "questions" that can continue to be calculated.
We are not faced with a choice between Hum-Free or Plurality. The real challenge is how to dialectically integrate these two vectors and design a society that is constantly transforming itself.

The ultimate goal of viewing society as a human computation is not to compute some particular "right answer. Rather, it is to keep the computational process itself in a **"computable" state** that can be forked, deployed, and redefined by participating humans at any time.

The governance of the future will not be a completed static system, but an open and dynamic **"governance platform "** where citizens can tap APIs, adjust parameters, and propose new modules. There, humans will not be objects of computation, but architects of computation, weaving the pluralistic value of [The world should not be ruled by one voice.] as code and as culture.

I've been too busy to organize my experiences and problems as a user side, but I'll give you some miscellaneous feedback:.

The fact that we were able to distribute the experience of "proposing one's own opinion" by Idobata to about 8,000 people is an achievement two orders of magnitude above the Tokyo gubernatorial race, and a world-leading case study.
The "problem of exposing raw error messages to users" was not resolved, resulting in a high volume of queries.

The behavior of running out of credits is simply an error because it is not designed to be an error, and the operation of continuing to put in credits to avoid errors is going to be a bigger problem in an organization that is slow to approve budgets.
Writing directly to GitHub made it difficult to handle that data mechanically.

Since collecting information from GitHub API is rate-limited, we needed a system to collect and store the differences in order to analyze all the cases, which we did throughout the first half of the project.
In terms of ease of latter-stage processing, I'd like to put it in a DB and have a GET API.
No mechanism for prioritizing the many proposals that come in.
I tried to post on X and like on GitHub, but it was difficult because the system is separate and requires a separate account, so it would be better to have it on Idobata itself.
Quadratic Voting?
Need a confluence of similar proposals, perhaps written directly to GitHub, making it difficult to handle from the system.

There are several people in charge of looking at proposals, and they are divided according to the content. Assigning this division was difficult (due to the difficulty in capturing data), and we were forced to use GitHub Actions to make it happen after the fact.
If it is generated as a raw modified diff, there will be a cancerous conflict between PRs, which is hard to resolve manually.

lines.text: Countries that do not recognize private ownership of land
[Private ownership of land]
[o3.icon]
Major countries where private ownership is not allowed
China (People's Republic of China)
Article 10 of the Constitution specifies that "urban land is owned by the state and rural and suburban land is collectively owned. Individuals acquire "land use rights" for a limited period of time.
Vietnam (Socialist Republic of)
Under the Constitution, land is "owned by all the people" and uniformly managed on behalf of the state. There are no private property rights; only land use rights are traded.
Laos (Lao People's Democratic Republic)

The amended Land Law of 2019 (consistent with the Constitution) provides that "Land is owned by the national community. The state represents and manages it". Grants the people the right to use the land for a long period of time.
North Korea (Democratic People's Republic of Korea)

Article 21 of the Constitution stipulates that "the property of the state belongs to all citizens" and that "natural resources and land are solely owned by the state. Individual land ownership is not allowed, and housing is treated as rental.
Eritrea
Land Decree No. 58/1994 declares that "all land in Eritrea is owned by the state. Citizens receive usufruct for life (usufruct).
Ethiopia

Article 40 of the 1995 Constitution provides that "the ownership of land shall be exclusive to the State and the peoples and shall not be subject to sale or other exchange. Agricultural land and other land is leased from the government for the right to use.
supplement
Cuba's 2019 constitutional amendment allows private property (limited) and not a complete ban.
The above countries have also developed mechanisms for the sale and inheritance of long-term use rights to redevelop urban areas and attract foreign investment.
Despite the strong image of "state ownership = socialist countries," strict regulations on state-owned land vary slightly depending on each country's history, political system, and land reforms.

Challenge) on September 30, 2012. AlexNet won by more than 10 percentage points, recording 15.3% of the top 5 errors compared to 25% in 2011, the previous year when hand-designed features dominated. [Cybozu Labs Study Session]
Is the prediction market like a futures market?

[o3.icon]They are similar in that they both involve the buying and selling of contracts for future events, the prices of which represent the expectations of market participants. However, the essence of futures trading is "transfer of price risk," while the essence of prediction markets is "probability estimation through information aggregation" - the purpose, clearing method, and regulatory framework The purpose, clearing method, and regulatory framework are very different.
Request to write about calculations
If I were to write a book now, what would it be, and I decided that society is about calculation.
Overall, we're talking about society, using computer science concepts such as "widening the bandwidth of IO" and "pure functions have the same output if they have the same input."
Will the voice of those with money be louder in the forecasting market?
It depends on the theme whether it is better to be or not to be.
The market is basically a system where those with money have a louder voice.
Deciding by one vote per person is a mechanism to prevent those with money from having a louder voice.
Instead, the minority is suppressed ([tyranny of the majority]) because the voice of those with strong opinions and the voice of those with weak opinions are the same one vote.
Q: Allow minorities to be disadvantaged or allow the rich and poor to be disadvantaged
A: The action against the rich-poor gap is a mechanism of "[redistribution]" that takes private property from those who have money and distributes it to those who do not have money. This is not good.
On the other hand, using it for all policy decisions puts minorities at a disadvantage.
Q: What if everyone has the same amount of chips and we distribute them and vote on them?
A: That's Quadratic Voting!
QFs that increase voting rights based on the "amount of donations" rather than handing out a fixed amount of votes.
This is also a good amount of grant for OSS in the form of [Gitcoin].
Predictive markets are not likely to solve the problem of public goods being destroyed.
I'm sure that's true in the current forecast market alone.

When you make a predictive market for venture investment, spending on projects that have the potential to succeed in the future, you create an incentive to invest money in creating a public good that is beneficial to you.
Public goods investment in QF or [Retroactive Public Goods Funding].
I'm talking about carbon credit trading to acquire the cost of preserving forests, a public good.

Dishonest Infinite
The phrase "insincere infinity" reminded o3 of Hegel's "[bad] infinity," but here we will examine the usage of the phrase "insincere infinity" in Japanese.
There must be people who use the key word in Japanese, "insincere infinity".[nishio.icon]
[o3.icon]
Summary (key points first)

In the Japanese-speaking world, the term "insincere infinity" is used not as a philosophical term derived from Hegel, but mainly by those who reinterpret it as a metaphorical expression in the Web3 and political tech communities. In particular, it is frequently used in the four-quadrant model of "sincerity/dishonesty × finite/infinite" proposed by Shogo Ochiai (@shogochiai) and his surrounding community, and has spread to Team Mirai supporters and critics, blockchain-related events, and individual bloggers. The following is a list of major senders and examples of usage.
1. core originator
1.1 Shogo Ochiai (sg / @shogochiai)

He posted several tweets that problematize the "︎ (upper left) = dishonest infinite" in his own four-quadrant model. ([X (formerly Twitter) https://twitter.com/shogochiai/status/1922892163995599211?utm_source=chatgpt.com])
I guess this is the first.[nishio.icon]

>[shogochiai https://x.com/shogochiai/status/1920582237570875603] Pension and other system designs implicitly have "infinite" in their logic, but as soon as they meet any of the following criteria: they can't be infinite in the first place, they are borrowing in advance from future generations, and they are vulnerable to a black swan event," it falls apart as soon as any of these are met. We call this a "dishonest infinite." And the next institutional design will do the same thing.

Some of his statements are light-hearted in developing the concept, such as "[Immortality as an insincere infinity], that's nice." ([X (formerly Twitter) https://twitter.com/shogochiai/status/1922891894478053681?utm_source=chatgpt.com])
1.2 tkgshn / 0xtkgshn

Published a Scrapbox page "Dishonest Infinite" with redacted sg concepts, and a set of synonyms "Sincere Finite". ([Cosense https://scrapbox.io/tkgshn/%E4%B8%8D%E8%AA%A0%E5%AE%9F%E3%81%AA%E7%84%A1%E9%99%90])

He presents a critical framework of "an argument that says nothing = an infinity of dishonesty" with the example of Akio Hoshi's critique of human rights theory. ([Cosense https://scrapbox.io/tkgshn/%E4%B8%8D%E8%AA%A0%E5%AE%9F%E3%81%AA%E7%84%A1%E9%99%90?utm_source=chatgpt.com])
2. derivative users/communities
User/Medium Example/Context Reference

k-yamashita (@chekichekimusu1) "Team Mirai's "disloyal finite" is..." and policy theory applying the four quadrants. ([X (formerly Twitter) https://x.com/chekichekimusu1/status/1936698441532604437?utm_source=chatgpt.com])

Kengo Yamashita, Scrapbox Team Mirai Critical Article on the Ideology of Endless Improvement (i.e., Dishonest Infinity). ([Cosense https://scrapbox.io/yamashitakenngo-60893617/2025%2F06%2F22?utm_source=chatgpt.com])

Anonymous Twitter Discussant: "I feel that the use of 'honest finite' and 'dishonest infinite' is incorrect..." and discussion of the meaning of the terms. ([X (formerly Twitter) https://x.com/chekichekimusu1/status/1936698441532604437?utm_source=chatgpt.com])

In the ICP Japan Blog Saga Meet-up Report, the social system is organized in four quadrants and introduced as "Upper Left, Lower Left = Dishonest Infinite/Finite". ([ICP Japan〖Official〗 https://www.icp-japan.org/post/ai-crypto-deai])
ICP HUB Japan Official X Post a summary of this blog and spread the concept. ([X (formerly Twitter) https://x.com/icphub_JP/status/1939496016648229115?utm_source=chatgpt.com])

Chama (@defi_chama) Contrasts brand-buying behavior with "dishonest infinity" and likens Uniqlo to "honest finite". ([X (formerly Twitter) https://x.com/defi_chama/status/1950301518575653303?utm_source=chatgpt.com])

Political discourse around Team Mirai "Populism is dishonest infinity," etc., used as diagnostic labels for policy discussions. ([Cosense https://scrapbox.io/tkgshn/%E8%90%BD%E5%90%88%EF%BC%88sg%EF%BC%89%E7%94%A8%E8%AA%9E?utm_source=chatgpt.com])

Web3/AI Risk Study Group Article Using the Four Quadrant Model to Position Accelerationism as a "Dishonest Infinite". ([ICP Japan 〖Official/Official〗 https://www.icp-japan.org/post/ai-crypto-deai?utm_source=chatgpt.com])

Repeatedly mentioned in the Scrapbox corpus glossary page and functions as a simple dictionary. ([Cosense https://scrapbox.io/tkgshn/%E8%90%BD%E5%90%88%EF%BC%88sg%EF%BC%89%E7%94%A8%E8%AA%9E?utm_source=chatgpt.com])
3. implications of the concept (reinterpretation in the Japanese-speaking world)
1. modern replacement of Hegel's "The Evil Infinite
It has the same root in that it criticizes [the attitude of endless outward flight], but it is used more as a metaphor than as a philosophical rigor.
2. anti-patterns of policy and technology development
It functions conveniently as a label to point out the condition that keeps saying "it will get better someday" without showing a concrete finished version.
3. web3/ai risk context
It is a widespread warning against positions of uncontrollable risk, such as "accelerationism" and "infinite growth." ([ICP Japan 〖Official/Official〗 https://www.icp-japan.org/post/ai-crypto-deai])
4. critical words for discussion attitude

He calls statements that only superficially present "correctness" without substance "insincere and endless," and urges sincere and finite proposals. ([Cosense https://scrapbox.io/tkgshn/%E4%B8%8D%E8%AA%A0%E5%AE%9F%E3%81%AA%E7%84%A1%E9%99%90])
4. summary and observation points
In effect, coined words around sg spread through Twitter, Scrapbox, and blogs.
As the four-quadrant diagram is shared as a visual memo, others easily cite and transform the concept.
In the future, there is a possibility that this term will spread beyond Web3 and political tech as an anti-pattern term in policy evaluation and project management.

Thus, "insincere infinite" is a keyword that has evolved uniquely in the Japanese-speaking online community, and by following the source and examples of usage, lines of values and criticism among the community can be seen.

Taiwan's Digital Democracy and Ethereum
2025-08-02 At this point, both sides are starting to think it would be a good match, but it hasn't come to fruition as a clear practical example yet.[nishio.icon]
[o3.icon]

The "collaborative governance with citizens at the center" that Taiwan's digital democracies (g0v, vTaiwan, MODA, etc.) espouse resonates deeply with the idea of "supporting public goods with blockchain" fostered by the Ethereum ecosystem in terms of philosophy, institutional design, and technology. The two have begun to complement each other in three ways: (1) emphasis on transparency and open source, (2) new voting and fund distribution mechanisms that allow people to make their voices heard even with small amounts, and (3) the goal of maintaining public goods on a global, collaborative basis. The structure and specific examples are organized below.
1. the Foundations of Taiwan's Digital Democracy
1.1 g0v/vTaiwan's civic hacker culture

The g0v community, born in 2012, continues to develop open source and policy proposals in the spirit of "forking and reforming government (.gov)" and has achieved consensus building through the citizen participation platforms vTaiwan and pol.is ([Wikipedia https://en. wikipedia.org/wiki/G0v_movement?utm_source=chatgpt.com]).

The "crowd-source → step-by-step consensus" model using pol.is has shown results in policy formation, such as Uber regulation and COVID-19 mask rationing, and has attracted global attention ([blog.pol.is https://blog. pol.is/pol-is-in-taiwan-da7570d372b5?utm_source=chatgpt.com], [WIRED https://www.wired.com/story/taiwan-democracy-social-media/?utm_ source=chatgpt.com]).
1.2 MODA (Digital Development Department) and "Plurality"

MODA, to be launched in 2022, will deal with "democratic participation, cybersecurity, and the digital industry" in the same organization, with "plurality" as its policy principle ([govinsider.asia https:// govinsider.asia/intl-en/article/turning-conflicts-into-co-creation-taiwans-digital-ministry-moda-harnesses-digital-policy-for- democracy?utm_source=chatgpt.com], [TIME https://time.com/6979012/audrey-tang-interview-plurality-democracy/?utm_source=chatgpt.com ]]).

A framework for co-creating public rules is being developed through deliberative + AI-based workshops called "Alignment Assemblies" for each project ([moda https://moda.gov.tw/en/press/background-information/5543]).
Public goods mechanism provided by Ethereum
2.1 Quadratic Voting / Funding

Quadratic Voting (QV) and Quadratic Funding (QF), which emerged from the Ethereum community, were proposed as voting and fund distribution methods that would reflect "strength of approval" while also picking up minority voices ([Wikipedia https://en. wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadratic_voting?utm_source=chatgpt.com], [Woodstock Fund Blog https://blog.woodstockfund.com/2021/05/20/quadratic- funding-a-better-way-to-fund-public-goods/?utm_source=chatgpt.com]).

Real-world operations, such as Gitcoin Grants, multiply small donations to support OSS and public goods projects ([Gitcoin https://www.gitcoin.co/blog/gitcoin-grants-quadratic-funding-for- the-world?utm_source=chatgpt.com], [Gitcoin https://www.gitcoin.co/blog/how-gitcoin-is-unlocking-the-potential-of-public-goods- across-asia?utm_source=chatgpt.com]).
2.2 Ethereum Foundation's Public Goods Orientation

The Ethereum Foundation (EF) is seeking to collaborate with governments and the civil sector, with an emphasis on ZKP and privacy technologies and public goods research ([moda https://moda.gov.tw/en/press/background-information/5543 ]]).
3. specific examples of interactions
3.1 Adoption of QFs in Policy Implementation

The "Innovations Benefit Society - Call for 100 Proposals" in 2023 by ADI under MODA, in collaboration with three domestic crowdfunding companies, was the first government project to officially adopt QF ([MODA https://moda.gov.tw/en/ADI/news/bulletin-board/5451]).

The RadicalxChange Foundation also reports that "the Taiwanese government has begun using QF for public project financing" ([RadicalxChange https://www.radicalxchange.org/media/blog/designing- pluralistic-mechanisms-for-quadratic-funding/?utm_source=chatgpt.com]).
3.2 Direct Consultation between EF and Taiwanese Government

In 2024, Audrey Tang and Aya Miyaguchi of EF and others met in Taipei and confirmed their plan to jointly study "using Web3 for public goods in Taiwan" and "democratic AI alignment by ZK-ML" ([moda https://moda.gov.tw/en/press/ background-information/5543]).
This conversation is.[mashbean]も参加してるね[nishio.icon]

MODA hosted a Web3 event with Vitalik Buterin and also announced its support for acquiring a Taiwanese "Digital Gold Card," suggesting a long-term collaboration ([MODA https://moda.gov.tw/en/ press/press-releases/9355?utm_source=chatgpt.com]).
3.3 Ideological Mutual Influence

In an interview, Audrey Tang emphasized the overlap between Plurality and Ethereum's public goods philosophies, stating that "diverse actors should support public goods by utilizing decentralized infrastructure, including blockchain, as a collaborative technology" ([CoinDesk https://www. coindesk.com/consensus-magazine/2024/05/22/audrey-tang-learning-from-taiwans-digital-civic-experimentation?utm_source=chatgpt.com ]).

Wired describes Taiwan's civic hackers as "a movement to redesign democracy through blockchain-like collaboration" ([WIRED https://www.wired.com/story/we-will-see-the-rise-of-civic-hackers? utm_source=chatgpt.com]).
3.4 Web3 Utilization on the Citizen's Side

The Taiwan DAO community has raised funds through Gitcoin-Asia rounds and other means to fund g0v projects and social issue-solving apps ([Gitcoin https://www.gitcoin.co/blog/how-gitcoin-is-unlocking-the- potential-of-public-goods-across-asia?utm_source=chatgpt.com]).
4. complementarities and challenges
table:_
Perspectives Strengths of the Taiwanese side Value provided by Ethereum Challenges
Transparency Public documents and budgets via API Immutable blockchain ledger Joining on-chain information and administrative data
Expand participation Voting reflecting "strength x number" by consensus building UI QV/QF such as pol.is/Join Identification and Sybil resistance (ZK-ID, etc.) implementation
Public Goods Fund National Budget + Crafan Smart Contracts for Automatic Distribution Gas and L2 Selection, Legislation
Privacy MyData, etc. Individual Sovereignty ID ZK-proof for anonymous voting and verification Legal integrity and UX
5. future prospects
1. ZK-citizenship: Pilot operation of anonymous/guaranteed one-person, one-vote online voting using ZK-ID.
2. public goods dashboard: visualize national budget and on-chain subsidies in the same UI, and citizens can check QF matching rates in real time.
3. alignment assembly on-chain: Put the voting and subsidizing part of the AI policy debate on Ethereum L2 to facilitate international participation.
4. international comparative study: jointly explore optimal institutional parameters by comparing the Taiwanese model with outcome measures of global Web3 public goods such as Gitcoin.

Taiwan's approach to democracy as a "recursively upgradeable public good" is a good match for the open and verifiable collaborative platform that Ethereum has implemented - their collaboration could be a touchstone in shifting the value of blockchain from "speculation" to "cooperative governance. The collaboration between the two could serve as a touchstone to shift the value of the blockchain from "speculation" to "cooperative governance".

malignant infinity
from  [Dishonest Infinite]
malignant infinity
[o3.icon]
summary

The "infinity of dishonesty" is another translation and paraphrase of schlechte Unendlichkeit (English translation: bad infinity; Japanese: "bad infinity," "untruthful infinity," etc.), which Hegel criticized in his "Grand Logic. This is "an infinity that never completes itself, as it keeps escaping outward from n to n+1, each time exceeding a finite number," in contrast to the "true infinity" (true infinity) that Hegel affirmatively defends. ([hegel.net https://hegel.net/en/v11123froeb.htm?utm_source=chatgpt.com]) This paper briefly summarizes (1) the organization of the term, (2) its theoretical position in Hegel, (3) its application to Marxian economics, and (4) its development in contemporary thought.
1. terminology and translation

Bad Infinity/Untruthful Infinity - A negative concept used by Hegel synonymously with "infinite progression (Endlosigkeit). In Japanese studies, "bad infinity" is the fixed translation, but it is also translated as "insincere infinity" or "untruthful infinity. ([takamuratetugaku.org https://takamuratetugaku.org/015/015_07_text.html?utm_source=chatgpt.com])

True Infinity - A wholeness that is self-contained while encompassing the finite. Often likened to a "circle". ([afterxnature.blogspot.com https://afterxnature.blogspot.com/2014/11/bad-infinity.html])
2. position in Hegel's philosophy
2.1 Definitions

A bad infinite is "a state in which the finite is negated and only extends outward, and the negation itself is repeated" ([hegel.net https://hegel.net/en/v11123froeb.htm?utm_source=chatgpt.com]). Mathematically, examples include infinite lines and sequences 1, 2, 3....
2.2 Contrast with true infinity

Hegel uses the "circle" as a figure, and calls the structure in which the finite and the infinite are not in opposition, but in which the finite is subdued in the infinite, the true infinite. ([hegel.net https://hegel.net/en/v11123froeb.htm]) The dialectic that overcomes the bad infinite and moves to a self-inclusive whole is the core of his "Absolute." ([hegel.net https://hegel.net/en/v11123froeb.htm?utm_source=chatgpt.com])
2.3 Range of Criticism

Hegel criticized Kant's theory of antinomy and the concept of theological transcendence as falling into a bad infinity because it remains an "external counterpart of the finite and the infinite". ([Core https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/74373179.pdf?utm_source=chatgpt.com])
3. succession to Marxian economics

Marx saw capital's self-propagating movement M-C-M′ as "an evil infinity of endless quantitative growth" ([Marx Online Library]). ([Wiley Online Library https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/ejop.13078?af=R&utm_source=chatgpt.com]) In modern times, David Harvey has described "the madness of capitalism, which wants to keep growing at 3% forever. ([jacobin.com]) In modern times, David Harvey has likened "the insanity of capitalism, which tries to keep growing at 3% forever" to a Hegelian "evil infinity". ([jacobin.com https://jacobin.com/2018/07/karl-marx-capital-david-harvey]) Capital that assumes infinite expansion runs into geographical and ecological limits, creating the paradox of "never-ending growth = never-ending crisis." ([Cambridge University Press & Assessment https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/hegel-bulletin/article/hegels-logic-and-marxs-concept -of-capital/9F9E2411E0BBFE54CD0D4DC04B6DEBEB?utm_source=chatgpt.com])
4. development in contemporary thought

Critical Theory and Hermeneutics - Gadamer emphasized the finite nature of man and argued that "Hegel's totalization leads to a 'bad infinity'" ([Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/gadamer/?utm_source=chatgpt.com])

Post-Hegelian - Reexamination of the "bad/dishonest infinite" in the context of Bataille and Schelling reassessments. ([Miyako Tori https://tokyo-metro-u.repo.nii.ac.jp/record/9991/files/20037-002-018.pdf?utm_source=chatgpt.com])

Critique of Political Economy - "Endless government debt issuance" and "the scale supremacy of digital capital" are discussed as bad infinite modern allegories. ([davidharvey.org https://davidharvey.org/2016/12/david-harvey-marx-capital-lecture-6-bad-infinity-madness-economic-reason/?utm_ source=chatgpt.com])

Mathematics and Logic - The distinction between "possible infinities" (potential infinities) and "real infinities" (completed wholes) in discussions of infinite sets and paradoxes still inspires Hegelian problem setting. ([Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/infinity/?utm_source=chatgpt.com])
5. summary

The "insincere infinite/bad infinite" is Hegel's critical concept that the infinite, which is supposed to be beyond the finite, is actually unable to break free from its dependence on the finite and simply repeats negative motions. The transition to a true infinity is only possible through a wholeness that encompasses the finite and is self-contained - dialectical cessation. This distinction has been widely cited from Marx's critique of capital to the contemporary critique of growth supremacy, and continues to provide a fundamental question for the unfinished, ever-expanding system.

[gpt.icon] [Alexis de Tocqueville.] was a 19th century French political thinker who elaborated on the concept of the "tyranny of the majority" in his celebrated work, [Democracy in America]. This concept contains a warning that the power held by [the majority] in a democratic system may threaten the rights and liberties of the minority.... Tyranny of the majority refers to the danger that matters decided by majority rule in a democratic system are not always just or fair, and that the majority may use its power to suppress the opinions and rights of the minority. Tocqueville warned that the majority can undermine the freedom of society as a whole by excluding from society those whose opinions differ from its own and violating their rights.

In the case of an issue permanently divided into majority and minority, the domination of the minority in the name of the majority can be rationalized and justified.
